The aromas are of that characteristic wheaty twang, bananas (but much less than what some of my friends describe as "holy cow this smells like banana!"), bit of clove and spice, and a yeasty goodness that wraps up the aromas nicely. The flavors are very much like that of the aromas. A very slight hint of earth in the finish. Well carbonated and light bodied. Makes for a good summer beer.  Now, I must admit that I do not like wheat beers. The wheat twang kills it for me. If I were to rate this to my opinion, it would be 5/3/3/3/3, where my 5 would be given to the presentation of the beer. Take that as you will, I suppose.

Poured from it's pint .9 bottle in to a legit hefe glass  A - significant foam head that is a chalky white in color; nice lacing; straw-yellow in color; some cloudiness present  S - smells like a dried biscuit; has some banana and clove notes; a little bit of Belgian yeast and just a hint of orange peel and fruit syrup  T - bananas; a touch of bubble gum; biscuit; wheat; lightly malty  M - really solid balance of flavor, sweetness, and carbonation; very light-bodied; crispy; perfect to enjoy in the summer  O - this is really one of the best 'globally' available hefes you're ever going to find; the balance, crispiness, smooth flavor profile, and general drinkability are all admirable.

Time to get started for New Years' Eve! Off comes the top of a 500mL bottle, and in to a heavy mug it goes. 3:1 foam - so far so good.  Smell consistent with good wheat beers, with a fresh subtle scent of hops, and fruit cocktail.  Taste was well balanced and refreshing. It is smooth like the golden color it exhibits.  This will pair well with the barbequed pizza I made from scratch (Sundried Tomato, Carmelized peppers and pepper chicken)  For me, a top 10 beer.

A - Cloudy amber with massive soapy head; I had to pause mid-pour to allow the head to subside a bit; Moderate lacing on the glass  S - Biscuity with notes of orange peel  T - Biscuit, clove, orange zest. Hint of bubblegum. Yeasty tart finish  M - Fizzy, light body; pleasantly coats the mouth; smooth drinking; mild warming sensation from the alcohol  O - Pretty solid, but honestly I was expecting better based on reputation. I'd like to try this on draft sometime to see if it's markedly better. A solid hefeweizen that I will definitely drink again, but not the best I've had.

Had it on-tap at Beerosophy, Bangkok, served in a Weihenstephaner weizen glass.  The showcase is somewhat nearly immaculate with a hazy yellow amber color and a thick fluffy white head. When the head retention and lacing left are exceptional, the aroma and flavor drive forth so mellow, inviting, fresh yet balance with a big touch of fruity ester, citric/lemony zest and bubblegum that nicely parade with a sweet biscuity malt and clove with a spice while wheat with a twang. The feel is smooth with a velvety body and refreshingly crispness/dryness. No doubt this beer is cult, my veneration to the old Weihenstephan again.

The Weihenstephaner Hefeweißbier was my go to weekend morning beverage when I was studying in Allach, Germany, a small Bavarian town just Northwest of Munich.  A - Cloudy, milky, and golden  S - Sweet, sugary, balanced aroma  T - Perfect for pairing with typical Bavarian foods - Weißwurst und Breze, Sweet and refreshing  M - Not too overpowering, well balanced  O - A great true Bavarian Hefeweizen, possibly the greatest  ** Claims to be the oldest brewery in the world - whether it is true or not is irrelevant.

The beer pours much like the kristallweissbier, but with more pulpy appearance that slightly hints at pink as it pours into the glass. In the glass, the beer looks a lot like cloudy dehydrated piss, with a huge big, creamy, white head. The body is quite hazy, sitting somewhere in between the clarity of apple juice and the murkiness of apple cider. Lacing is fat and sticky on the sides of the glass, leaving puffs like the clouds in the sky. On the nose, the beer smells wonderfully of spicy banana breads, with nice clove notes, and some definite hints of mint in the afterlingerings of the scent. There is even a slight spicy pepper in the scent, sitting below the other rich scents. The smell is thicker and richer than the kristallweiss’s (obviously) with a much grittier and natural flavor.  The beer tastes richly of bubblegum banana with clove spice notes. The beer begins with bubblegum and spice; just as it is building in flavor a slight yeasty funk can be felt in the taste, but is quickly washed away by the big banana bread flavors that have been building in the mouth. This eventually wanes down into a banana aftertaste with light clove and bubblegum hints at the sides of the tongue. The mouthfeel of this beer is superbly creamy, with light carbonation and a medium to slightly heavy and leaves the mouth with a thick sticky feeling on the tongue while the mouth as a whole feels clean, but slightly coated in candied banana. Overall, this is a superb hefeweizen, as would be expected from the oldest brewery in the world. I hold this up there with Zero Gravities Weizenheimer as the best in the style. A superb beer that epitomizes and optimizes the style beautifully. This beer is a must try.

Wow! Easy-drinkin'...  Very sessionable crisp clean and smooth on the tongue. Perhaps my next go-to hefe for the Summer.  A - Golden, hazy straw. 1/2 glass full of tiny white bubbles. Lots of fine lacing.  S - Banana bubblegum wheat...  T - Reminds me of Allagash Whte without the sour bite at the end... Absolutely delicious for someone looking for a lighter feel and taste. The banana is sweet and savory! Will DEFINITELY buy again...  M - Crisp and sweet... Light and refreshing  O - Almost in my top 10... I think it easily is a 4.5 beer.

I poured a bottle into a weizen glass.  Appearance- Cloudy golden color with two fingers worth of lingering, foamy head. Fair amount of lacing.  Smell- Big aroma of wheat and yeast with some banana and bubblegum notes.  Taste- Wheat malt, orange, banana, and clove. Very well blended together.  Mouthfeel- Medium bodied and very smooth. Perfect amount of carbonation with a slightly creamy feel.  Overall- Great beer. This is the best hefeweizen that I have had. I can't wait to pick up some more of this.

Nice cloudy golden yellow. Lots of fizz. Thick, fluffy head lingers forever  Slight spice and yeast in aroma. Crisp and funky.  Awesome flavor. Yeasty, slightly spicy. A little bit of that banana flavor people get from Hefes.  Great, smooth mouthfeel. Creamy. Carbonation feels just right. So lingering bitterness.  Really great beer. Not as great after it starts to go flat, though.

Bottle served in a Hacker Pschorr Weiss glass.  A: Pours a hazy straw color with some amber hues in the body. I heavy white head forms on the pour and recedes very slowly leaving behind sheets of lace.  S: Big orange peel with some cracked wheat and spicy yeast. Coriander and banana with a slight sweetness.  T: Much more wheat flavors in the taste. Coriander, orange flesh, and sweet yeast.  M: Medium bodied with a little bit of chew to it. Medium-low carbonation. Sweet finish.  O: Very solid hefe. The taste was spot on, but it didn't quite live up to the complexity of the nose. Would enjoy again.

This is one of the first beer in a 5 pack that i bought today. The ultimate Bavarian gift pack, with 1 traditional weizen glass.  Poured the hefeweissbier into the glass. Just wow. This glass and the beer in the glass in so enticing. A huge fluffy white head about 4 fingers thick forms and stays for a while, dissipating very slowly. Head retention is good. Pale straw in color. Totally cloudy and unclear as expected. Good amount of bubbles can be seen rising from the bottom of the glass. Very small sized bubbles here. Decent lacing as well. Appearance is near perfect.  Smell is more phenolic clove like, with a good amount of banana fruity esters. Fairly good balance here, just a tad more prominent on the phenol side. Good characteristic smell of wheat beer. You know you are going to encounter some sweetness.  Taste is very much the smell. Mix of clove and banana flavors. Sweet in taste. A good wheat presence. Some tartness due to high carbonation. Not exactly very dry finish.  Mouth feel: light to medium bodied. Refreshing effervescence due to carbonation, which is too much, exactly as per the style. Good chewy feel.  Style wise. It is the epitome of style, no doubt about it. A well deserved 4.75. Personally a good 3.75 for a wheat beer.

Not sure when or where I first had this, but I've had it several times over the years, bottled and on tap.  Pale golden-yellow pour, hazy, with a tall fluffy white head; decent retention and a bit of lacing. Yeasty aroma, bready, banana esters, clovey spice, pretty much exemplary of the style. The taste reflects the nose, pale bready malts, doughy, toasted wheat, classic hefe yeast, banana and clove. Medium body, fairly smooth mouthfeel, soft carbonation. This is where you go for a no-nonsense hefeweizen.

12 oz bottle that was purchased in Las Vegas with the code 1282 stamped into the back. Poured into my perfect pint glass.  Appearance: Easily the most massive head I have seen, white, solid and 1/2 the glass. The beer is a hazy straw color. Leaves some lacing as it goes.  Smell: Yeast, wheat, lemony phenols, clove, bubble gum and a little band-aid. Exactly how a good hefe should smell.  Taste: Delicious wheat with citrus overtones, most from the yeast and maybe a touch from hops, I suspect. Clove comes out a little more strongly in the taste. Actually pretty thirst quenching. This one does not bowl you over with intensity (big stout of IPA) but the flavor has a tone of great quality.  Mouthfeel: Smooth texture and a lower amount of carbonation (due to the massive head) make for a great feeling beer.  Overall: These guys have been brewing this one for a while, so I imagine that they have perfected this style. I would tend to agree. For some strange reason, this one is not available in Utah, and that is a shame.

Pours a golden-orange color with a huge, fluffy white head that looks like a cloud atop the brew. Super volatile, even a somewhat conservative pour gives this thick-ass head. The nose is full of yeast, wheat, malts, light spices including clove and maybe coriander, and a faint hint of fruity sweetness. The taste follows the style of hefeweissbiers very closely (after all, this is the original as they say), full of sweet fruity esters; banana, faint lemon and orange zest, hints of clove and kitchen spices, and a rush of sweet malt, and a cyclone of pure yeast, extremely reminiscent of bubblegum. Alcohol makes an appearance, although very faint at 5.4% ABV, it provides a nice structure to control everything else. Wheat on the tongue and breads and yeast in the aftertaste - this beer is delicious. Lots of carbonation provides a nice, crisp snap on the tongue; thin-medium body.  The claims they make about this beer aren't false or even exaggerated - this is some truly great stuff, here. One of (if not, THE) best hefe I've had - this is quickly becoming one of my favorite session beers; great flavor, low ABV, goes down smooth. What's not to love?

Poured a nice, vibrant amber with a thick white head that diminishes slowly over the course of the 500ml beer. The taste is about what I remember from enjoying this beer frequently while living in Germany, still a nice fruit finish and that wonderful hefe mouthfeel. Overall a great buy, especially for someone looking for a more authentic German experience thanks in large to the 500ml service size. Of all of the wonderful beers I had in Germany, this one seems closest to the real deal as any I've had.

Poured from a 22 ounce bottle into a Samuel Adams pint glass. Purchased at Wakefield Liquors in Wakefield, RI.  A- Pours a very hazy, golden orange with a thick, heavy 4" head. Little retention with no lacing.  S- Dark fruit upfront, wheaty, bready, sweet notes in the background. Subtle but inviting.  T- Wow. Upfront, cloves, heavy wheat, nice spiciness. Ends with fruity, grapefruit, and slight citrus notes. This is what I want to taste in a hefe. I can't decide between a 4.5 and a 5.  M- medium high carbonation. Not heavy, just crisp and refreshing. Highly drinkable.  Overall, this is an excellent hefeweizen. Tasty and complex, while maintaining a crisp, smooth character. I could drink this all day, every day. I didn't expect anything different. I will not compare this to the standard, because this is the standard.

Poured in a Weizen glass  A- pours a slightly hazy pale golden color with an orange hue. Huge rocky and pillowy white head, sustains long after the pour and reduces to a solid layer leaving sticky lace on the glass.  S- Classic banana and cloves, earthy, cellar like yeast. Sweet wheat with a hint of lemon-grass, just a trace of hop bitterness. Very nice.  T- Sweet malted wheat, highlighted by somewhat tart lemon notes and a bit of clove. Hops are minimal, finishes dry with a cracker like maltiness. The yeast is a bit nutty and I pick up some refreshing fruity notes as well. The alcohol is noticable but is balanced nicely. The linger on the palate is fruity and refreshing, long after tasting.  M- medium body with a healthy bit of carbonation, mouthfeel is super creamy and goes down like velvet.  O- this one lived up to the hype for me. By far the best Hefeweizen that I've had and will enjoy this one many times to come. I can only imagine having one of these fresh overseas.

I know I have had this beer before… I just don’t remember it. Oh, and sorry we have not written in a while. I was in Dallas on business, and have just been really busy lately. But we have some new motivation… before I leave for a week on another business trip! Anyway, tonight we are grabbing a bottle of Weihenstephan Hefe Weissbier. I wonder if anyone out there can pronounce the name of the brewery… not you German readers. Other readers!  Anyway, looking forward to reviewing this beer. I don’t have an orange. I hope I can still enjoy the beer!  In the Glass: It’s light yellow in the glass, and pours a two-finger head. The lace is weak, but the head stays strong when swirling the beer in the glass back and forth.  Nose: That is what a beer is supposed to smell like. It is filled with yeast and has a subtle dryness to it. I just want to take a big chug of this. Like I said, I know I have had this beer before… just not sure what it tastes like. Based on the style, I need an orange. But I hear it’s not cool to fruit your beer.  Flavor: This isn’t ice cold, as we just bought the bottle tonight. But I threw it in the freezer when we got home. It is at cellar temps right now. Perfect for most, if not all beers. The flavor is incredible. Never mind the bubbles, the flavors are that of a typical hefeweizen. I haven’t had one of these overseas yet, but the next time I go over there, I will be sampling one of these. By the way, did you know that Bayerische Staatsbrauerei Weihenstephan is the oldest brewery in the world?  Mouthfeel: There is a ton of carbonation. The beer sits nicely on the tongue, but as you swallow the bubbles really try to force all that flavor to the back half of your palate. The flavor is nice, but the mouthfeel, and I hate bubbles… is acceptable. I wouldn’t want to swish this one around in my mouth… as that wouldn’t give me any more flavor, only create more bubbles… but man, what an enjoyable beer.  Aftertaste: The aftertaste is decent. Nothing to write home about. The ABV is also pretty low, and what aftertaste I get is subtle, dry, and reminds me of why an orange would match well with this beer. I am not a huge fan of this style, but the hot Arizona summers might change me in a few years. The crisp flavor a beer like this produces will help cool down those hot summer nights nicely.  I am not a huge fan of this style, but I really enjoyed this beer. As my palate changes, I have to keep an open mind on beers that I might not always dig. For example, I HATE Brettanomyces beers… there is just something about that yeast strain that I can’t handle. Not sure of the yeast strain they use here, but man… I could get used to drinking beers like this. Beers like this might even taste better from DAS BOOT!!!  Weihenstephan Hefe Weissbier – The bottle says: “NA”

So easy to drink anytime of the year. The head is so impressive, it almost looks like dessert. Almost makes you want to buy more Weizen glasses. Consistently good. A great beer to always rely on. Yet another great beer from the world's oldest brewery.

A - Pours golden bronze with a two and a half finger frothy white headm leaves a decent amount of lacing.  S - Honey, lemon, citrus, clove, adjunct grains, slight wheat, and sweet malt.  T - Bubble gum, lemon, citrus, light wheat, honey, banana bread. Bubble gum is dominant however  M - Medium bodies with low carbonation. The wheat becomes more pronounced and the honey and clove linger on the tongue. Extremely smooth feel to this beer.  O - Over, I never thought i'd find a top 100 beer for $2.19 a bottle, but I'm glad I did. This is very easy to drink and much better than La Fin Du Monde.

Gotta give a disclaimer here first. I have tried this beer before—on many occasions. This is one of my favorite beers on the planet. I’ve been told it is the perfect Hefeweissbier. Now I haven’t had enough of the style yet to truly appreciate the differences, but that being said, I can vouch for how good this is. It is amazing.  A – A hazy gold with a perfectly white head of carbonation that rises up to the top of the glass when I pour it but then recedes afterwards. Very little/no lacing.  S – Makes you wanna cry. The smell is just so goddamn wonderful. Clove and banana, bread and a very welcoming yeast with hints of spice as well. AAAHHH, smells so good...also, bit of lemon.  T – A lot more of the nose, just such wonderful flavor, a perfect balance of bitterness and sweetness, great banana and yeast, with other fruity (lemon) and spicy components in the background (maybe a little caramel in here as well, just a dash).  M – The carbonation on this beer is really nice, it provides a luxurious effervescence that tingles across the tongue and down the throat. The body is medium.  O – I love this beer. It will be a beer that I drink for years to come. Great, wonderful, tasty, delicious, banana-y, sweet, bitter, mild, drinkable, spicy, yummy.

.5 liter bottle to a Horseheads pint glass  A- Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a giant head of thick white cream that stays for quite a few minutes. Limited lacing.  S- Extensive amounts of bananas, a bit of lemon and some grassiness along with some spice. This is a real winner here.  T- More lemon and yeast character than the nose lets on, but otherwise follows it. Lots going on with banana and citrus, finishing up with a subtle warming on the way down.  M- Light on the tongue, but that's the way it should be. Very bubbly and refreshing. A certain lasting spiciness brings me to take another sip.  O- I really enjoy SN Kellerweis, but this might surpass it. This is surely one i'll go back to again, especially at 3 bucks a piece.

A: A cloudy golden yellow, I could not tell if it was transparent because of the glass I was drinking out of, a nice big off white head at the top and left very slight lacing.  S: Lots of banana, slight hint of caramel, and wheatyness and spice.  T: Perfect tasting wheat beer, banana that hits you at the end with some spiceyness, and good amount of wheat.  M: MediuM bodied and slight amount of carbonation, just the perfect amount.  O: I enjoyed this brew very much at BIergarten in Hoboken NJ, a great wheat beer, very drinkable, and great for the summer.
This is my favorite style and the best beer I've ever tasted. On tap or in bottle, sheer perfection.

A A hazy yellow, orange color with a 3 inch head. A mass of carbonation flowing to the top of the glass. Leaving a beautiful lacing all around the glass as I drink poured into a Dry Dock Hefe glass. S Bananas, Clove a nice slight bubblegum and a bready like maltiness with a minimal citrus hop aroma.. T Banana, Clove, biscuit malts, bubblegum wonderful taste going on here. M Highly carbonated and easy drinking has champagne like mouthfeel with a nice clean finish. Lingering banana, clove on the finish.. O A fantastic Hefe all around, one of the best Hefes on the market. I can see why they have been producing beer for ages. If you have never had it I suggest trying it out it is well worth it....  Cheers

Golden colored, cloudy, and with lots of carbonation. I got a two finger creamy and rich looking pure white head. The retention was superb as it lasted till the end. This beer is absolutely stunning in my Weizen glass. Mostly what I smell in the beginning are those fruity ester aromas from the yeast, mainly it's banana. I also detect cereal grain/biscuit that adds a balance to the sweet fruit. I'm also picking up a hint of lemon. Initially I taste some earthy/herbal hop flavors followed by biscuits and and those yeast esters which again remind me of banana. Like the aroma it finishes with a lemon zest. It's medium bodied and is noticeably smooth especially when you consider the level of carbonation. Hops give way to the malts and yeast and finally there is a citrus finish, making this one interesting beer. What a fantastic beer to enjoy while I sit here and watch football. I could see having this in about any scenario or season. The price was great too for the quality of this well known world. Lass beer. I paid 2.99 for a pint. I'll do that again for sure.

Appearance: Pours a hazy, yellow/orange with four fingers of fluffy, white head. Good laceing, head resembles meringue.  Smell: Nice mix of hops, citrus and bready malts. I get some clove and banana as well.  Taste: Grains and hops. nice citrus notes. Slightly boozy towards the end  Mouthfeel: Very smooth, with more body than any other hefe i have tried. Very nice  Overall: Lives up to its reputation.

500 ml poured into weizen, intense carbonation, four finger soapy head  Smells: yeasty, wheat, and a tinge of fruit  Taste: banana, bubblegum, cloves, and the booze  Mouthfeel: Bubbly, a champagne like experience.  Overall, this is a good beer, but I would not say it is the best hefeweizen that I have ever had. I would not go out of my way to have this beer again any time soon.

Outside of the hefeweissbier served at the Andechs Monastery in Munich from their oak barrel, this is the best hefeweissbier you will ever drink. Perfection in a glass. One of my favorite beers of all time. Ayinger's hefeweissbier comes close but Weihenstephaner have mastered the hefeweissbier.  Pours a hazy, golden-hued liquid into a weissbier glass. Head is perfect as not too much and not too little. Lacing is light. Smell is light citrus, bright cloves and subtle malt. Mouthfeel is light on carbonation and alcohol. Taste is a brilliant explosion of malt, bready yeast, clove/banana and delicate sweetness. Finish is smoother than water off a duck's back. No bitterness at all. While most weissbiers lean one way or the other on the sweetness scale, Weihenstepher nails the balance perfectly. One of the best beers in the world.

Special thanks to my girlfriend’s parents for bringing me back a Weihenstephaner gift pack straight from Bavaria. They’ll never see this, but I just wanted to mention them!  500 mL bottle poured into a Weihenstephaner weizen glass at fridge temperature.  L – Very hazy deep gold color with an enormous 7-finger white frothy, creamy head. Excellent retention and a little bit of lacing. A little half-finger white frothy cap sits on the surface of the beer all the way down the glass.  S – Bready and grainy wheat, banana, cloves, and a little bit of bubblegum. Smells absolutely fantastic.  T – Follows the nose with a taste that is just as robust as the aroma – something that is difficult to accomplish judging by the small number of beers that have equal tastes and aromas. The beer is sweet all the way through with bready and grainy wheat malt, lots of banana esters, and a little bit of bubblegum. As the taste progresses, yeasty clove spice really picks up. Delicious.  F – Light-to-medium-bodied with great carbonation, a crisp but creamy mouthfeel, and a spicy and pleasantly dry finish. Spicy yeast lingers for a really nice amount of time.  O – This is an absolutely fantastic hefeweizen. It’s easy to see why it’s rated the best. Everything is so nearly perfect for the style that it’s tough to not give this one 5s across the board. The fact that it’s so readily available in the US makes it even better. Without a doubt, this is a must try for all beer-lovers.

On tap pours cloudy with white head. Aroma is clove and banana. High carbonation adds to the tingly mouthfeel. Flavor is a perfect balance of clove and banana and is the best beer to represent this style. Upfront you get the tingly carbonation, then the banana clove hits the middle and finishes semi dry Outstanding.

From a 500 ml bottle into a hefeweizen glass.  A-Pours a light golden color. Hints of orange. Not clear, but not as foggy as I would have expected for a wheat. The head is incredible...really tall, just off-white in color, thick, and long lasting. There is pretty significant visible carbonation.  S-The smell is my favorite aspect of this beer. It smells like banana with a touch of lemon and clove for a kicker. A touch of hay and grass keep things from being too sweet. Really nice.  T-Sweet yeast with banana and a touch of lemon/citrus and clove. No real hop character and just a hint of alcohol. Well balanced acidity...no need to muck this one up with a lemon wedge.  M-Lots of carbonation, but very drinkable. Dry on the finish, but never tart.  O-This is a fine example of how to brew a wheat beer that is drinkable on a hot summer day without tasting like a watered-down mess. It has more backbone than most wheats without tasting gimmicky.

It's foaming right out of the bottle, pour it slow gents. Or chase it around the table.  A hazy August gold with a super tall dense yet fluffy white foam crown sitting atop. Down below lots of carbonation buoy the foaminess.  Smells great. Lots of pleasent malts, yeast with there clove and bananana aromatics.  Good drinking and easy at that. Bold wheat malts and yeast play a nice match, with banana esters coming through. Even a hint of clove.  On the palette all goes well, smooth and refreshing. It holds it flavor well as it warms, since I think wheats tend to go flat or water out as they warm. It's a lazy rainy day. Watching birds at my feeders even saw a bold eagle at peace valley park today, simple man is on the computer.... So simple man I think works well this this wheat.

500 mL bottle. Pours a murky dark yellow with a decent two-finger white head. Fairly high carbonation. Nose of yeast, bananas, orange peel, lemon zest- standard wheat beer. Taste brings out some cloves and citrus tartness. Fairly light bodied but excellent. Nice dry finish. Inferior to New Glarus hefeweizens. 12/7/2008 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

A 500ml bottle with a BB of Sept 2012. Picked up from a supermarket a while back. Been meaning to review this one for ages - beer from the world's oldest recorded brewery!  Poured into a straight pint glass; I swirled the bottle before the final pour. A deeply hazy, translucent golden-amber hue with effervescent carbonation. Produces a large head of creamy off-white foam that lasts for a few moments before collapsing. Aroma of sweet malt and yeast esters, with notes of banana, clove, bread, faint nutmeg and a mild whiff of alcohol. An initial metallic hint fades away after a little while. An earthy, vinous quality lurks in the background. Complex and superb.  Tastes of sweet malt with a dry, yeasty character. Notes of banana, clove, bread, faint honey and subtle stewed hops. Possesses a mildly tart dryness, as if infused with a hint of lemon. A bone-dry finish; no bitterness to speak of. Mouthfeel is smooth, dry and tingly, with pleasing carbonation and great body. Thick and chewy. Somewhat astringent, with an aftertaste of yeast esters and banana.  Simply put, one of the world's greatest beers. All the characteristics of weissbier are superbly blended together - the yeast esters produce a fantastically balanced flavour and aroma. An easy-drinking classic; very refreshing and I could happily imagine sinking a few. Add this to your list of must-try beers.

This is the beer I want when I want a hefe weizen.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a Hefe glass. Always save that last little bit at the bottom of the bottle to swirl around and get that yummy yeast at the bottom. Pours a hazy yellow with a full head. Minimal lacing.  Smell is banana nut bread goodness. Bananas, clove, biscuits, nuts.  Taste like it smells. Very well balanced. Delicious from start to finish. Yeasty.  Mouthfeel is very thick and perfect carbonation.  Overall this is and has always been one of my favorite beers. Yummy goodness!

Pours a nice cloudy yellow with a full white head. Quite a few bubbles, this is what I picture a wheat beer as looking like.  Probably the strongest smell of any wheat beer I have ever tried. A bit bread like at first from the malt and yeast, but there is also a fruit smell, a lot of banana, and a nice amount of clove.  A lot of banana and clove, a bit of fruit. Bit of a bread like taste in there as well. Very flavorful beer, a lot going on here.  Excellent mouthfeel, no complaints here.  Easily the best wheat beer I have tried. Some beers I know from the first sip are something special, and this is one of them. Lives up to it's rating, an excellent beer.

Been a while since I touched a Heff, good change of pace again.  Served from a bottle to pint glass.  A- Hazy amber, great carb bubbles dancing their way up to a tight creamy head. There was barely any retention on the head, as it disappeared quickly into a thin cap that skimmed the top of the beer.  S- Bananas, Yeasty Bread, Some Wheat and a Pinch of Clove. Very inviting.  T- Palate follows the nose big time. Cloves, bananas, a little yeasty, sweet malted wheat, light citrus. Very complex flavor that paints a mosaic of great taste. It all comes together too perfectly and finishes well.  MF- Light-Medium body with a medium carbonation to it. Very tasty beer that goes down plain and simply smoooth! The flavor really hangs around on your tongue and the roof of your mouth.  O- Worth it for me. I got tired of wheat beers and heffs quickly, but this proved to be a worthy contender in a vast sea of complex beers out there. For a moderate price, jump on it! Delicious.

Appearance: Hazy gold to dark straw. Lively carbonation. Bright-white, creamy head starts off massive and pillowy, but drops to a 1cm cap that persists in large part because of the carbonation. Looks refreshing.  Smell: Clove, banana, and some grass. Peppery undertones. Bright clean almost lemon. Yeast is slightly earthy. Wheat. Some bright pale malts. Very clean. Melon?  Taste: Malted wheat. Almost toasted. Lemon, grass, perfectly ripe banana. Underlying spiciness drops hints of clove and pepper. Yeast is earthy. Mild roasted character. Bright and clean. Big fruity esters push some apple and pear. Almost no hops to speak of.  Mouthfeel: Lively carbonation. Body runs just on the thin side of moderate. Lingering dryness builds with each sip.  Overall: Summer the beer.  This is a staple in the style for a reason. Loads of flavor, never overbearing, and delightfully refreshing.

Cloudy, golden color. Lots of fine carbonation rising. Thick frothy head.  Tons of banana in the nose. Sweet bread, cloves, vanilla, touch of lemon.  Sweet bread up front. I get lots of banana, cloves, vanilla, bubblegum, slight lemony. Very complex in flavor. Refreshing, very soft body and finish.  Truly the best Hefeweizen.

A: into weizen glass; stirred up and then poured sediment in: soft hazy gold beer with a fluffy white head  S: faintly ripe fruit, wiffs of dry wheat fields and floral yeast  T: sweet, fruity, wheaty malts, mild banana and gum; well-balanced with the bitterness  M: soft, creamy, full-bodied and light at the same time  O: I cannot imagine a better hefeweizen. The challenge is to not give this beer 5's across the boards - but I honestly don't think this recipe can be improved upon or bettered. This is a seemingly perfect beer of the style, but have allowed for personal tastes and such. Certainly a hefe you must have when exploring the style.

Appearance: It has a nice cloudy golden/orange color to it. It has a very nice thick white head that dies down very slowly and leaves some lacing.  Smell: The aromas definitly give out hints of yeast, bananas, wheat, spices (mainly cloves) and some slight citrus.  Taste: Like the aromas, it has some nice cloves, bananas, wheat malts, yeast and citrus. Great tasting Hefe!  Mouthfeel: It has a medium carbonation with a nice overall balance and feel.  Drinkability: It's a very smooth drinkable beer accompanied with great flavors and aromas. One of my favorite beers.

Picked this up on a lark based on the recommendation of the beer counter guy in a grocery store of all places. Good job beer guy.  Average hefeweiss beers are a dime a dozen. It's an easy style of make average / okay, a hard style to screw up. But on the flip, it's a hard style to distinguish yourself in it seems.  This is one hell of a beer to stand out. Pours with a towering thunderhead of dense foam into a weiss glass. A hazy golden, with swirling bits of yellow orange yesty goodness.  Smell is nutmeg, clove, vanilla and banana with a nice yeast aroma.  A subtle sweetness in the mouth. Very smooth. Exceptionally smooth with a nice spiciness and teensy bit of bite. There's some alcohol taste when it warms a bit, which kind of surprises me given the 5.4 abv.  Fantastic beer. Glad to have tried it. It's so smooth and so true to style that this ought to be the benchark for hefe weissbiers the world over.  Loved it. This isn't a session beer. It's a drain the bottle and have three more before you even realize what happened beer.  The simplicity of it blows me away. This is one of those beers that should illustrate that yeast doesn't just add fizz and alcohol to a beer, but actually makes the style.

Poured into pilsner  A: A very foggy medium orange color with a beautiful foamy white head  S: a very smooth, appetizing smell that i love and stands out tremendously in this brew  T: Wonderful, kind of a roasty taste. Banana stands out a lot which tastes delicious  M: Mouthfeel is very good, that yummy banana leaves a great taste, wish i could have that flavor on my tongue all day.  Overall a fantastic beer and you dont have to be a beer wiz to tell. It Proves that you dont need an overwhelming amount of ingredients/flavors to make an excellent brew.

After a week or so of devouring stouts and porters, I tried this one at the behest of my girlfriend. As is almost always the case, she was right. This is a good beer. It pours and looks like a typical American lager in some ways, but that is where that comparison ends for me. Right away I was struck but a banana smell and taste. I didn't expect that, for I had never had a banana tasting beer before. I quite liked it. Overall, this is an easy-to-drink refreshing lighter beer that is very satisfying in its splendid and unique taste. Me gusta.

No idea what the freshness is like, 5491 printed on the label. 16.9 oz bottle into a tall pilsner glass. When I opened it it gushed over and the bottle had a large layer of sediment on the bottom.  A - Lightly hazed golden amber body. Massive fluffy bone white head. Amazing retention and lacing.  S - Huge bannana presence. A touch of clove, spicy yeast, wheat, and some biscuity crackers.  T - Underipened bananas, clove, yeast, spices, and bready malts. Very tasty and refreshing. Well balanced and light, but full of flavor. Mouth feel is lightly syrupy yet crisp and well carbonated.  O - Certainly the best hefe I have tried. This is a style that is hit or miss for me as I lean more towards the banana flavors than the clove flavors. This one is very banana heavy with just a touch of that spicy clove. This is an excellent beer.

A: Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a huge white fluffy head that settles fast and leaves little lacing.  S: It has a strong banana aroma with some spiciness coming though.  T: There are some banana and spices coming though with slight amount of bitterness in the finish. Overall it has a mild but pleasant taste that is typical of a wheat beer.  M: I would say it has an average level of carbonation with a medium body that is slightly sticky.  O: Overall a very good wheat beer that is perfect on a hot summer day. While it is not my favorite style of beer it definitely does this category justice. Would buy again.

Poured from a 16.9 oz. bottle into my Spaten weizen glass.  Appearance: Hazy golden yellow. The bright white head exploded up the weizen glass with a pleasing burst of effervescence. Very long head retention but almost no lacing.  Smell: Very nice. Spicy and a lot of wheat. Cloves and banana are also quite prevalent...no surprise there, of course. Smells spot on for the style.  Taste: Wow. Great tasting. Yeasty and spicy. Loads of cloves, bananas, and a touch of bubblegum. Hint of warmth at the finish. Pretty much the definition of a hefeweizen.  Mouthfeel: Light bodied with a spritzy touch of carbonation. Wonderfully drinkable.  Overall: I'm kicking myself for waiting so to try this beer. I enjoy hefeweizens immensely in the summer and this is the hallmark of the style for certain.

Golden yellow in color with a slight unfiltered haze. Poured with a tall, rocky white foam with good staying power. Sweet ripe banana and spicy clove aromas with bready and yeasty hints in the background. Rich, smooth feel with refreshing crisp carbonation. Sweet banana flavors down the middle with clove around the edges. A touch of tangy bitterness toward the end as this finishes crisply and cleanly. An extraordinary summertime ale.

I get it, this is a really great beer. It's definitely the best German Hefeweizen I've ever had. I just don't think the style is for me. That banana & clove combo just doesn't make it a beer I can fully enjoy. Again, I'll reiterate, this is by far the best beer I've had in this style. I can appreciate one when it's good, even if I don't reach for it voluntarily.

Review from 2/2010 notes. Poured into a Celebrator pokal. Pours a dark golden yellow with two fingers of white foam and lacing. Wonderful aroma of clove, banana and wheat. Dry wheat start and middle with banana and a pleasant, spicy aftertaste of cloves. A nice well integrated, tasty wheat beer, very nice. This beer blew my mind the first time I had tried it, really the first time I had a light colored, relatively low ABV beer that tasted fantastic. One of the world's great beers.

This is a fantastic wheat beer. I am a huge Blue-Moon fan and this beer with its citrus characteristics really made me feel at home.  The color is a beautiful amber. The taste is light with definite citrus. The only place where this beer lost any points in my book was in carbonation. On-tap it didn't seem overly carbonated but when I had a bottle of it my first pour had a lot of head and seemed about right. The second pour I may have been to gentle and the carbonation definitely got in the way of what I would consider the perfect mouthfeel.

Tulip glass.  A: Two fingers of beautiful, snow white, fine head on an opaque light gold body. Excellent retention.  S: Lots of spice (clove), wheat, and a little malt.  T: Banana and clove, the spice up front throughout the sip, very creamy body, with a medium length finish which leaves banana on the palate.  M: Light carbonation, medium-full body. Milk-like in how creamy the body is.  O: Excellently crafted, an archetype of the style.

Poured into a Weizen Glass. Dark yellow-orange with lots of head, 2-3 inches! Lots of visible carbonation. Smell was earthy, yeast heavy with very little of the fruit/citrus I expected. Taste was great! The smell made me think the taste would tend toward the bitter but here the fruit came more to the front. It wasn't as sweet as some american versions but very palatable with more hops. I picked this up with no expectations or foreknowledge of the brand. I just knew it was a Hefeweizen I hadn't tried yet. My new benchmark!

Pours a nice golden yellow color, very hazy and cloudy, with a two finger frothy white head that sticks around. Not much lacing.  Smells strongly of bananas and bread. Also has some notes of cloves and slight orange peel smell. Very pleasant.  Lots of bananas and some spiciness on the tongue. Paves way for some bread notes and very low hop bitterness. Slight orange peel taste and some spiciness in the aftertaste.  Good carbonation in the mouthfeel. Nice medium body and had some chewiness into it. Goes down real easy and smooth.  Very nice hefeweizen. Never tasted such strong banana notes before in a beer. Great drinkability and magnificent in the summer. This bottle held up very well despite being two and a half months away from the best before date. I am curious to see how much better it is fresh.

Poured into the token weizen glass  A - A rich hazy yellow with a big frothy white head that gives a nice retention.  S - Banana, orange and a lot of sweet bubblegum-like scents coming though. A lovely aroma for sure.  T - Follows the nose with some additional flavors: yeast and clove. Makes for a superb drink.  M - Dirnkability is at its finest with this one. A wonderful light-medium body bursting with flavor while remaining tightly tamed. It feels soft and refreshing on the palette. Fantastic.  O - In my opinon the best of the style. Others try to do what this does but are simply caught short. A truly wonderful brew that any enthusiast should seek.

330ml bottle into a pint glass.  Pours a hazy dark yellow with a billowy white head. Decent head retention but somewhat lacking in lacing.  Wonderful aroma of bubblegum, clove, banana, and oranges. This is really what a Hefe should smell like.  The flavor has Lots of banana/bubblegum yeasty esters along with some clove. Everything is fairly well restrained with no single characteristic becoming overpowering. The soft wheat mouthfeel along with fairly high carbonation makes this one refreshing beer.  Overall, one of my favorite Hefe's. Really a benchmark for the style and a beer everyone should try.

Poured a gorgeous cloudy, yeasty golden color with a two finger fluffy white head that receded to a ring of white foam leaving lacing on the glass. An excellent appearance, very true to style. Near flawless. Scents of clove, banana, slight citrus, some wheat malt and a low level of vanilla. A very good aroma profile that hits the style dead-on. Nothing is off, everything is present and it's all fantastic. Very nice. Flavor begins with spicy cloves phenols and a bit of banana esters, moving into more clove phenols but now balanced equally with banana esters and a slight citrus-like sourness. An undertone of cracker-like malt is present throughout the entire sip. Finishes with an equal balance of banana esters and clove phenols, with a slight lemony sourness. Aftertaste is spicy clove phenols and faint banana esters. An excellent flavor profile. The main flavors of the style reveal themselves in full form and several of the optional flavors also come into play. Very well done, balanced and refreshing, perfect. Mouthfeel is light bodied, effervescent with high carbonation and a slightly creamy feel. A very nice, refreshing mouthfeel that is perfectly true to style. Overall this is an amazing hefeweizen. Everything about it is a perfect representation of the style, and this is my number one recommendation to anyone who wants to try a good Bavarian hefeweizen.

This is a mighty fine hefe! A very tasty brew for the summer time... Taste of bananas, cloves, wheat with a very smooth finish. I could drink these by the pool, by the river, by the swimmin puddle all day long. They say there is a drought out there, but I can't believe it as long as I have one of these in my hand!

A bottle of 330 ml. Poured into a weizen glass with a capacity of 300 ml. This one pours great, gave me a huge white head, 4 fingers in height with great retention. When it finally came down, a thin strip of foam remained on the beer's surface. Pale golden colour, slighty hazy. Sweet aroma of bananas and clove, less strong once the foam goes down of course, but still there during the whole drinking time, and quite pleasant. Taste is also just a bit sweet and fruity, with some spices and yeast traces. Rich body and as mach carbonation as needed. Leaves your palate dry. A great beer, maybe I will seek it again after I finish my three other bottles.

The pour is great! It's a cloudy golden-yellow with lovely thick head. Smell, bananas and clove (as it should be). The taste was light banana, little clove when taken with some of the head. Without taking in the head with a drink, the banana was distinct and complimented well by clove and a wheat-like taste that fills the mouth. It isn't super yeasty. Carbonation and head adds to a splendid mouth-feel.

poured into duvel tulip.  Appearance: golden yellow bodied beer with a light haze noted to the body, not quite opaque though. The beer has 2 fingers of white head that drops down to a thin cap, but has some decent staying power. Spotty lace.  Smell: Big bananas, wheat malts and clove.  Taste: Follows the nose really close. The bananas are not as big in taste as they are in the nose. A nice malty wheat base is found mid palate. Yeasty and fruity notes are all over this beer. Finishes with cloves and more bananas imparting some sweetness.  Mouthfeel: light bodied beer with moderate carbonation. This beer is really drinkable and also delicate. World class carbonation and mouthfeel!  Overall: This is a tried and proven beer right here. German beer lovers get your hands on this beer. $3 for a 500ml format bottle what a fantastic price for an amazing beer! It wont dissapoint you... i dont even like this beer style, but I think that they make this beer PROPER! The oldest brewery in the world is getting things done the right way!!!  paired this beer with brick cheese and it worked really well.

11.2oz bottle  Hazy golden orange with a dense and rocky head.  Nose has bits of lemon with a savory bread character.  Creamy mouthfeel right off the bad with some more bread and a snappy crisp bite. Carbonation is higher than I anticipated but this adds to the overall refreshing character. More lemon zest and a perfect amount of clove.  So easy to drink and everything is in perfect balance. I couldn't ask for more on a nice hot day.

500ml bottle poured into a weizen glass.  A- Pours a very translucent yellowish golden, with tons of fast rising carbonation bubbles, and a big fluffy white head of about 3-4 fingers. Leaves some thick fluffy lacing along the sides of the glass.  S- Bannana, spices, bready, a little bit of earthiness and some lemon zest.  T- Nice fruity taste of bananas, bready yeast, wheat, some light spices, and some floral hints. Finishes with a nice sweet honey taste that lingers for a while.  M- Light, smooth, incredibly drinkable, great summer beer.  O- Hefeweizens usually aren't my favorite beers however I definitely enjoyed this one, definitely the best I've had so far and at $3/bottle you absolutely can not beat the price. Very nice fruity/bready flavor that is well-balanced, full of flavor, and very pleasant combined with an insane drinkability you have a very fine beer. Highly recommended, I will probably be picking up more of these.

Poured this into a weizen glass.  A: Pours a cloudy golden yellow color. Huge head takes up about 4 inches of glass. Some lacing is left on the glass after. The head quickly subsides.  S: Smells of banana, clove and a faint hint of bubble gum. Some citrus and wheaty yeast are also picked up upon further sniffing.  T: What a beauty this is. I get some spicy clove and wheat initially. The citrus and banana work together afterwards and there is a slight taste of bubble gum that comes through at the end/aftertaste. This sets the standards for how hefes should taste.  M: Refreshing. I could easily put down a whole sixer of this on a nice summer day. The drinkability is wonderful and it is a medium-bodied brew.  Overall: Hands down the best hefeweizen in the world. There is no question about it. One of my favorite all time beers and my go-to for the summer months. The balance and drinkability (aside from the taste) is what sets this beer apart from the other hefeweizens. You can drink your pale ales and IPAs in the summer, I'll take a Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbier!!

Appearance is a beautiful gold which pours a very large head which dissapates but a ring stays. The smell is very delightful. Smell bubblegum, bannana, cloves. The taste follows the nose which is filled with the fruit and spice. The mouthfeel is a medium thickness. Overall I really like this beer. Very refreshing and see why it's well liked. This will definitely be a part of the rotation during these summer months and may find myself drinking this from time to time year round. Very delicious.

Thank god for imports!  Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbier is an instant favorite. Coming from the "oldest brewery in the world" it should be no surprise that this beer is crafted to perfection.  I bought this in a "Beers of the World" 10-pack from World Market hoping to expand my taste profile. WH was a fantastic surprise find in the box, and I have since bought more individual bottles from my local warehouse.  Immediately upon opening the authentic Bavarian bottle, I smelled the light, sweet wheats and banana complex without having to search for it too hard.  The taste, again, was banana ,the icon of bavarian hefeweissen beer. Their use of it is perfect. It is a highlight of the beer, not the entire taste. There was additional spice notes that provided a strong finish. The entire bottle was great.  Highly recommend and worth keeping a few on hand at all times so you can introduce friends to it.

Been a while since I really drank a serious hefe, so I wanted to give one I knew was good a drink and a review. Drank this many times before, just now getting to reviewing it. Side poured with low vigor into a weizen glass.  Appearance - I love the labeling and the history behind this brewery. Simple, old school, tells you right up front what you are getting. Pours a cloudy straw yellow color with a huge, dominating four finger pillowy head, looks like a cloud on top of the beer. Good lacing. Tons of sediments and carbonation inside the beer make this a top notch presentation.  Smell - Wheats, Breads, a little earthiness, but the primary smell was banana esters for sure. Powerful banana, fruit smell to the beer. Maybe even a little honey sweetness in there as well.  Taste - The heavy banana esters are still the primary favors, with a good secondary pop of cloves and a little spice towards the end as well. The breads and malts round out this beer. Very well put together, a very complete taste experience.  Mouthfeel - It's like eating a loaf of banana bread, drinking this. Big bodied, Thick creamy mouthfeel, big carbonation, excellent smooth finish. Hard to beat.  Overall - if you haven't had it, go get it and drink it. Excellent beer, almost unmatched in its category. Highly recommended, I will buy it and drink it again. There is a reason it is the top ranked hefe on all of BA.

Poured into a snifter  A: Opaque gold with a white one-finger head that lingers. thick lacing  S: Citrus, floral, wheat  T: Wheat, malts, honey, floral, light. Smooth.  M: Light to medium, strong carbonation.  O: Not bad, but certainly not the the king of hefe's. Perhaps I like my beers on the maltier side. A good summer beer, nonetheless; sessionable.

Poured from 500ml bottle to weizen glass:  Pours a burnt straw gold, very lively body to it. A swelling white head leaves good lacing.  Sweet malted wheat, honey, semi-stale hops, faint yeast, something floral.  Cereal malts, banana, sweet wheat, clove... an immortal beer.  Exceedingly drinkable. Dangerously so.  This beer is beyond tried and certainly true.

Poured into tulip, lacking a good hefe glass. Beautiful deep yellow with a slight twinge of orange. 2 inch head with good lacing which dissipates quickly and a fair amount of sediment. Great looking beer.  Smell is bananna, a little pepper and some definite funky wet earth quality.  Taste is very creamy to start with a nice sweetness and peppery finish with slight alcohol finish and leaves a sweet, creamy aftertaste. Very solid, more substance than white or Saison which have similar tastes for me.

Poured into a hefeweizen.  Appearance. Luminous translucent orange hued straw in color. Pours with 3 fingers of head frothy head, which leave ample lacing as it dissipates to a half a finger. Tons of carbonation rises form the bottom of the glass.  Smell. Prominent banana character up front. Bready maltiness behind that along with some clove and other spiciness.  Taste. Starts with a moderate banana flavor and some slight earthyness. A slightly tart and citric flavor cuts this leading to a more clove and spice heavy second half. A low, almost imperceptible level of bitterness is there as well. Some more mild tartness leads into a dry and slightly spicy finish.  Mouthfeel. A huge amount of carbonation breaks up a relatively full bodied brew.  My go to hefeweizen. Highly recommended.

Pours hazy yellow with a big head that has excellent retention and lacing. Just about perfect for the style. Wheat bread and light fruits on the nose. A hint of some citrus zest. The taste is astounding. The first thing I notice is the thick feel in the mouth. A very full-bodied hefeweizen. I taste the traditional cloves and banana, and a slight bit of citrus (very slight.) Some bread like wheat flavor comes out too. The hop flavor is very mild.  The perfect hefeweizen? Maybe. I haven't tried enough to say, but it's definitely the best one I've had.

Pours a hazy gold colour with a big, beautiful white head that leaves lacing on the glass. Smells of yeast, wheat, malt, banana and cloves. Tastes just like it smells. Big wheat and yeast flavour, some spiciness, wheat/malt backbone, with some green apples, banana and a bit of bubblegum. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, nicely carbonated, smooth, dry and a bit tart. Overall, a nice beer to have on a hot day.

Tasted this on tap at Uptown Pub. Only had a sampling but what I tasted was excellent. Would definitely get this in the future, and i look forward to doing a more in depth review. Thick creamy head, rich mouthfeel, banana clove and wheat flavors prominent, extremely smooth. Incredibly balanced and thick mouthfeel, I cannot exclaim that enough. Fantastic brew overall.

Poured from the bottle into a hefe glass. Pours the color of a fresh orange at first, and then when the yeast is added it turns a dark, hazy coppery orange color. I had to pour this beer, walk away, and then come back to finish the pour; the head was huge, fluffy, like a giant cloud with no lacing left as I drink it. The nose is very bright citrus, orange, coriander, and white bread. The taste is again full of bright citrus notes, with banana and yeasty sweetness. The mouthfeel is very creamy with the a nice touch of carbonation. Very delightful. Overall, this beer is a fantastic hefe that I've been looking forward to trying. It's a great representative of the style and hits all the right points perfectly. I will definitely stock this for the summer.

Consumed 6/29/12  Appearance: Hazy gold - pours with a giant, fluffy white head, leaves blobs of lacing, retains a cap forever  Smell: Soft, bready wheat and yeast - bananas and cloves, in nice balance, in nice moderation - a touch of something lemony - nice malt base  Taste: Nicely balanced and stupidly, remarkably clean-tasting, refreshing - "refreshing" is a flavor, right? - mild banana, clove, and a touch of lemon, bubblegum - some straight-up yeast, with some yeasty spiciness - very mild bitterness - lightly bready malts, with some light graininess  Mouthfeel: Medium, but so smooth that it feels a bit fuller - nicely carbonated, refreshing  Overall: Beyond classic  This is a relatively simple beer, but it has great strength in its simplicity. The wheaty malt profile and the yeast come together in a remarkable way. The balance works better than any Hefeweizen I've ever tasted. Seriously. I should have had this years ago.
Perfection! Towering creamy head, and taste that captures the essence of a weizen. Doesn’t get much better than this.....Classic and a standard for the style.

I've had this before so I mean... this is gonna be good.  A: Pours hazy light amber and looks like a sunset. Bubbly head carries a little bit of the color and it stays around forever.  S: Wheat, citrus, orange (which I think is a citrus but don't call me out on being redundant ;) )  T: ooh taste is not as good as on tap for sure. Wheat comes through big time but this bottle seems to have a little bit of bitter stale taste to it.  M: Perfect. Sits with a good body and crazy smooth. The bubbles are smooth as well rather than off putting.  This is for sure the best wheat beer I've ever had. Smooth and wheaty and it hits perfect. Certainly better on tap but a bottle is worth checking out. Light enough to be loved by the average drinker, flavorful enough to be loved by the avid beer drinker.

This beer when poured is a hazy bright orange in colour. While the aroma of malt and hops are present, you will be pleasantly surprised with the hints of clove, banana and even nutmeg! Quite delicious and you will definitely want to reach out for another!

This is a superbly balanced wheat beer. There is a nice lemony tang vying with a rich malty flavor. Hops are there to round out the flavor not to dominate it. The yeast in the beer makes the warm yellow color a bit cloudy. The head remains lacy through out the session. This is a beer that seems to satisfy every guest whom I've served it. It wont raise eyebrows but it tastes delicious.  Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbier is as easy to drink as its name is hard to pronounce.

appearance: Hazy gold color with a firm and full white top. Looks very tasteful.  smell: Banana, wheat and yeast. Bit of bubblegum.  taste: Banana sweetness, with a bit of a bubblegum taste. Yeasty and wheaty. Broken up by a tiny bit of citrus and a copper like bitterness.  mouthfeel: Medium bodied, creamy with a dry finish. Medium carbonation. Goes down well.  overall: A fine beer, but it's not my favorite Weiss beer. I didn't find that flavor making this a really special one like some others do. So i find it a bit overrated. I prefer the Konig Ludwig or Paulaner over this one. Also the Wiehenstephaner Vitus is more like how i like it. Still a very nice, refreshing and tasteful beer though.

(BA / BJCP)  Large billowing, moussy off-white head. Holds extremely well. Deep gold in color, with a light murky haze from the wheat. (5 / 3)  Moderate banana, light clove. Hint of vanilla. Medium light grainy sweet wheat. No hop. (4.5 / 10)  Moderate banana, light spicy clove. Moderately grainy sweet wheat. Light hop bitterness is supporting. No hop flavor. Balance throughout. On the dry finish, a delicate vanilla appears. (4.5 /19)  Medium-light body with high carbonation. Creamy. (4 / 4)  Refreshing, flavorful, bright, clean, and extremely balanced beer. It's incredible! (4.5 / 9)  ( 4.48 / 45)

Pours exactly as expected; a large, puffy white head and a thick, cloudy body that is yellow-orange. A thin film of white remains after the head dissipates. Smells of bananas and other sweet things. Not the slightest bit of alcohol in the smell or taste. Taste largely mirrors the smell. The mouthfeel is a little off-putting. I feel it is too carbonated for the style and makes an otherwise smooth brew a little spiky. Overall, the beer is a classic. It also makes for a good summer beer, nice and refreshing.

I'm impressed with the overall quality of this beer. The smell is not overpowering, giving off mild hints of Banana but primarily hops, malt, and spices. The appearance was average, but I must say after pouring this beer into a glass it does leave behind a nice head. What I was most impressed with was the mouthfeel and the unique taste. The mouthfeel was very creamy and smooth, with essentially no bitter points whatsoever. The hoppy smell threw me off a little bit, because there are so many other flavors that strike you prior to the slight hop aftertaste. Above else, cloves were the first thing I could taste. Banana was probably the second most pungent flavor, followed by wheat, yeast, malt, a bit of caramel, and hops. Overall a pretty solid beer. Not one of my favorite, but definitely something different and for its class a very good brew. I'd give it a 8/10.

A- exactly what you'd expect from Weihensteiphaner. mountainous, dense head  S- lots of banana on the nose. clove and barley sneak through as well  T- banana's up front and aggressive. powdery feel from the clove. tidbit of acidity slips through and makes a brief appearance and helps break things up a bit. gorgeous flavors of yeast and wheat linger  O- more than lives up to the standards set by their other beers. an absolute must have.

500ml bottle, split  "german night"  appearance: served in my hilliards can-pint, hazy straw-orange body, thick white foam, wavy retention. Shes a beaut' clark.  smell: banana, clove, crisp wheat, yeast, lemon rind  taste: banana, clove, bubblegum, light grassy hops, wheat cracker. flavor somewhat less pronounced than the aroma would suggest - was expecting a flawless hefe, and just didnt find it  mouthfeel: nice creamy body, quite a dry finish  overall: some highs and some lows - a benchmark of the style but not necessarily my favorite. I miss, *gasp*, dancing man wheat
A fantastic beer! And the best thing is... it's easy to find in the US! Very well balanced, complex and delicious. It's perfection in a bottle! Ones of the beers to try before you die!

500 mL bottle from the LCBO; best before February 22nd 2013. Didn't see this in stores around here until fairly recently, but having heard nothing but praise (and being a fan of hefes in general), I am pretty eager to try this one.  Pours a muddy yellow-brown colour, quite cloudy, topped with nearly three fingers of silky, creamy, sparkling white head. Great retention - the head hangs around for a significant portion of the pint, and leaves behind nice smears of lacing on the glass as it slowly seeps away. Fresh, yeasty aroma with prominent spicy clove notes; leans on the sweet side with lots of pale wheat malt, banana and light citrus zest. Very impressed so far.  I'm in love with this stuff after my first sip - it really is that delicious. Tons of bready wheat malt flavour supported by more of the banana and lemony citrus notes detected in the aroma, with a gentle clove spiciness in the background. Malty, yeasty aftertaste with a faint hint of clove that lingers. Medium-bodied, and a silky, prickly mouthfeel with the perfect amount of carbonation for a hefe. A bit chewy, with a slick coating left behind on the palate after swallowing. As drinkable as mana from heaven, but I'd rather savour it than slug it back.  Final Grade: 4.57, a nearly-perfect A+ grade. I am completely blown away by this - I've heard it was good, but that is an understatement because it's utterly incredible. Usually I can find at least one thing to criticize no matter how much I like a beer, but this is virtually perfect from my point of view: the golden standard of hefes.  [Updated Feb. 18 2014]  I picked up another bottle, primarily to compare this one side-by-side with some other German hefes (Schneider-Weisse, Erdinger, and Paulaner). Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbier remains one of my favourite wheat beers of all time, and it is easily my favourite hefeweizen - unbelievably drinkable, absurdly smooth and delicious as hell. The only problem with this beer is that it's not as widely-distributed/reliably available as the other three in these parts... but I can't say I'm surprised, as this is a world-class beer that people should be buying by the armful. A must-try.

P: Huge mountain of thick  3 finer meringue head that towers over a beautiful cloudy golden orange body. Head retention is amazing with marshmallow lacing.   S:  Spicy yeast, copper, bananas, clove, and a heavy dose of fresh wheat.  Once swirled bubblegum, citrus and timid phenol aroma fills the nose.   T/M:  Ultra creamy mouthfeel, phenol bananas, clove, and delicious citrusy wheat.  Finish is dry with red delicious apples and a subtle copper aftertaste.   O:  Wow!  This was amazing. I loved everything about it. The creamy mouthfeel the delicious wheat and delicate spices. A total favorite for relaxing and enjoying a refined brew. I will definitely enjoy this regularly.

1 pint, 0.9oz bottle served in a weizen glass.  pours a hazy dull yellow tone with a big two-finger plus (closing in on three) creamy off-white head. outstanding retention and lacing all over the place. outstanding presentation.  nose offers clove, banana, and a touch of another fruit i'm having trouble placing. apple, maybe, or peach. melon? regardless, a real nice aroma. the flavor doesn't disappoint, full of clove and banana mostly, with a few mutes citric notes. very tasty. would be the perfect summer beer - relatively light and refreshing yet no less delicious.  crisp, medium-bodied mouthfeel with medium-plus carbonation. extremely drinkable. a classic, easily my favorite hefeweizen to date.  originally reviewed: 02-15-2011

16.9oz bottle w/ no date  Looks like apple juice with a nice creamy head. Smell is spicy wheat, hay, apples, grass, with a flat bitterness. Taste is earthy: grass and hay, honey, clove, lemon and a touch of banana in the back. Dry and sorta cloying

Served in a Weizen glass.  Appearance: Light, but semit cloudy gold. Not too many bubbles but an overwhelming head on the pour which rose to just under two fingers length.  Smell: Light orange with a mix of banana, light malts.  Taste: Really complex and built for perfection. I mean this beer is packing punch when it comes to flavor, light banana, slight sweet citrus and after taste of malts.  Mouth: As good as it gets when it comes to a any hefeweizen, this beer is so smooth.  Overall: The truth is this beer is my favorite (and should be yours as well) Hefeweizen, With rich flavors and full-filling taste it would be harder to please any more. Have one and ask yourself for more, Salud!

Enjoyed 21 May 2012, reviewed from notes. Bottle say 0315. I think this translates to bottled on the day ending in 0 (30) of 35th week of year, 2011, which would be 30 August 2011.  Pours a gorgeous cloudy pale golden wheaty yellow. Massive 3-finger white head, super fluffy and dense, with amazing sticky lacing. Unsurpassed in this department.  Smell is buoyantly yeasty, full of banana, with some spice and nice crisp noble hops. Smells delicious. Starts out full and fruity, then relaxes into a crisp, dry, wheaty-yeasty yumminess.  Taste initially strikes me as bland. Quite wheaty, but the yeast doesn't show up as much here. A decent amount of banana on the back end. But overall, it's dominated by those herbal noble hops. I want more spice!  Feels light-bodied, but full in the mouth. Good carbonation, finishes pretty dry with just a bit of water lingering in the mouth.  Smells and looks better than it tastes. Which is unfortunate, because it smells fantastic.

500 mL bottle poured into a weizen glass  A- A cloudy golden straw color with a massive white head.  S- Bready wheat, cloves, bananas, touch of bubblegum and lemon.  T- Wheat, touch of earthy spices, cloves, bananas, hint of lemon, light fruitiness. All the flavors work very well together.  M- Smooth medium body, slightly chewy.  O- An awesome beer that I will not walk by again. A new favorite.

A: hazy yellow with large white fluffy head.  S: strong wheat aroma with distinctive clove nd banana whisps.  T: just as it smells. Wheat and yeast right away followed by the banana and clove flavors. Very well balanced and light tasting.  M: high carbonation; crisp  O: A very refreshing beer. great for a warm afternoon/evening. Flavors well balanced to avoid any over-powering flavors.

A: Beautiful hazy orange with a tall and puffy foam head. Very good retention with healthy lacing down the glass.  S: Fresh grasses, banana, orange, cloves, and an underlying baked bread aroma. Very clean and crisp aromas conveying a refreshing quality.  T: Pleasingly similar to aroma with ripe banana and wheat the most dominant. Tart apricot, plenty of clove, and a subtle baked bread-like malt backbone. Excellent taste profile with everything working very well together.  M: Medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Finishes with a near perfect dryness and a very pleasant chalky texture.  D: World-class hefeweizen that I will certainly be drinking again, especially throughout the summer season.

A-A cloudy orange, good carbonation with nice lacing.  S-Lemon, orange, wheat, yeast.  T-Lemon, orange, spice, wheat, floral notes all balanced together, complex.  M-Light in bodied with good carbonation  O-One of the best Hefes out there, not much more can be said.

12 fl. oz. bottle marked 8461. Sampled on May 20, 2012. When this brewery was founded in 1040 AD, I wonder if the very first brewmaster expected it would still be around nearly 1,000 years later. But with the cloudy, heady pale yellow pour leading up to a tremendous aroma of pale malts, banana, clove, and yeast, I can imagine how an 11th Century beer drinker must have been refreshed on a warm medieval day. The light body is satisfying for the style. There is a slight zing of citrus goodness in the taste with the same flavor sensations that were introduced by way of the nose. It finishes clean and easy. The original is still one of the best in the world.

On-tap at 2 Amys in DC. Had this one countless times, but never reviewed it  Beer pours a gorgeous hazy yellow-orange with a fluffy white head. Maybe it's seeing it in the Weihenstephan glass, but this beer looks fantastic. Smell is awesome as well, perfect hefeweizen aroma of banana and clove. Flavor follows the nose, this pretty much epitomizes what a hefeweizen should be. Mouthfeel is light-bodied with nice carbonation. Overall, this is probably the best year-round, easy-to-get hefe in existence. It's a great beer for a hot day, and very refreshing. The only things that hold this back from a higher score are that 1) hefeweizens aren't my favorite style and 2) it's not quite on the level of my two favorite hefes, the Andechs and the Live Oak.

Long awaited (haha, maybe three weeks) to have the 'Top Dog' hefe for my summer beer project. One and a half 11.2oz bottles filling up a Penn Weizen glass. Yeast swirled in.  Hazy yellow-orange with a dollop of cream-white head. Excellent retention. Good look. 4.0  Wet banana, smoky clove, herbal German hop zing, and light lemon peel. There's a light caramel note to the malt that's delightful. 4.0  Very pleasing firm banana, clove, lemon, tart orange, wheaty grain, light caramel syrup, hint of pear flesh, and Noble hops. There's a lot of clove in the back of the throat in the finish. Nice citrusy notes. No one element steals the show. 4.5  Pretty much a perfect mouthfeel. Creamy, but juicy. A little tart, working as an aperitif. Mild-to-medium carb that does its job for the style. Rich, yet quenching. 5.0  An epic hefe. Not sure if I prefer this one over the Schneider Edel-Weisse, but it's ALWAYS been damn tasty. Even better on-tap. Hope I can find a bartender to pour me one this summer. 4.5

Appearance is hazy gold and straw like with a huge white creamy head. Lacing sticks to the glass and a 1/2" layer of head hangs around to the last drop.  This beer smells great and has a strong aroma; can smell it almost a foot away from the glass. Strong aromas of lemon zest, bananas, and orange.  Taste is similar to the smell with a banana flavor up front and a lemony aftertaste. Is a very carbonated beer that has great mouthfeel; a light feeling beer that is full of flavor.  Overall this is a great beer, would really be good outside on a summer day. I don't drink this style much but will be picking up more as the weather gets nicer. Looking forward to trying more wheat beers to see how they compare.

Appearance: Golden yellow, cloudy, rich full creamy head, a lot of carbonation, excellent.  Aroma: Clove, banana, sweet smelling beer. As expected.  Taste: This is a flavor explosion. So much going on. Cloves, banana, but also lemony, honeydew melon. Not overly sweet. No off flavors. Long sweet finish. Very nice.  Mouthfeel: Medium, crisp, carbonated but not overly so.  Overall: An excellent example of this style, and this is one of my favorite styles of beer. This would be enjoyable with almost any meal or in any weather.

Aroma: Lots of clove. Fruity esters, lots of banana, orange and pear. Grainy wheat. No hops.  Appearance: Yellow with orange highlights. Looks like a pineapple-orange juice. Moderately cloudy, but I see through the other side. Inspection with a bright light doesn't produce and visible particles, just lots of large bubbles calmly rising to the top. Moderate white head with yellow highlights. Good retention.  Taste: Glorious flavor. Grainy wheat followed by savory banana and mild orange citrus. Spicy clove and some black pepper phenols. Very little yeast. Some mild floral alcohol. Some mild residual white sugar. Some pine shows up associated with the hops and yeast at the aftertaste.  Mouthfeel: Medium body. Mild carbonation which is both creamy and stinging. Oily overall and finishes and bit dry.  Overall: Impressively savory and pleasant. Surprisingly bold considering the style and ABV. The best I've had.

12oz bottle poured into a pilsner glass at fridge temp (colder than ideal). I really need to purchase a proper hefe glass. No idea how old this bottle is.  A: Pillowy four finger head sits upon a super fizzy ultra clear golden body. Great head retention. You could float a quarter on this thing.  S: Classic hefeweizen...bubble gum, banana, clove and bready biscuit.  T: Delicious. VERY delicate flavors. Biscuit, banana, clove and coriander. The yeast isn’t as prominent as other wheat beers I’ve had.  M: Refreshing...drinkability through the roof. Give me this beer during Octoberfest all day/any day. Nicely crisp and easy drinking without being dry and astringent. Smooth as Billy Dee Williams. Light-to-medium body, high carb and soft finish.  O: Everything I used to regularly get out of a Franziskaner but more refined (and not BMC owned). Really nothing revolutionary here...just tradition done well. My new go-to weissbier.

Poured from bottle into pint glass.  Appearance: Pours a hazy yellow/blond body with a tall (1.5) inch white head, small bubbles. Pretty wheat beer.  Smell: Strong herb wheat scent. I get some vanilla or banana pudding smell that's a little weird but smells good.  Taste: Sweet wheat start with a soft vanilla banana and spice finish that's crisp with a lemon zest zing. Very light Noble hop character and bitterness. Taste excellent.  Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Moderate carbonation. Very smooth with a zing to it's finish.  Drinkability: Great late spring throughout summer wheat beer. Some much more refreshing than the Pyramid hefe I had earlier today. I've had this beer plenty before but never got around to a seated rating.

A: pours a hazy straw yellow with a one inch head that becomes a foam layer on top.  S: spicy yeast with a bit of banana  T: the spicy yeast hits first, along with a bit of bitterness. It is all followed up with a big malt and banana flavor with some sweetness.  M: well carbonated, medium bodied, very easy to drink.  O: fantastic hefe, I have not had better in the style. I recently came back to this style after years of disregarding it. This hefe is well put together from the beginning to the end of the drink.

A: Pours a hazy golden yellow in color with tons of visible carbonation (that keeps going and going). The beer has an enormous three finger tall dense white head that has great retention - over 50% of the head remained covering the entire surface of the beer. Moderate lacing is observed. This is an awesome looking beer.  S: This is a great smelling beer. There is a strong presence of banana and clove along with some lighter notes of citrus and something almost like bubblegum.  T: Great tasting... There is a light presence of wheat along with the banana and clove. Light hints of citrus along with just a hint of coriander.  M: Light bodied with heavy amounts of carbonation. Slightly prickly on the tongue due to the high amounts of carbonation.  O: Very refreshing, very easy to drink, and very sessionable. This is a beer that I could drink all day long, oh wait... that is what I did when I was in Bavaria. This is my favorite Hefeweizen (and it is a style I really enjoy). This is delicious and a great beer.

Pours hazy yellow with a towering white head that dissipates slowly. There is excellent head retention. The aroma is of malt and yeast with banana and citrus. It's a bold and inviting smell. The taste is exactly like the beer smells. It has flavors of wheat and barley malts, yeast, citrus, and banana. There's a mild spiciness in the flavor as well. The flavors are very well balanced. The body is light. This is a very smooth and refreshing beer. The finish is crisp and dry. Overall, this is an excellent beer and a great example of this style.

A- Pours a hazy golden yellow with a nice off-white head. Nice lacing on the glass.  S- Coriander, clove, light banana, slight citrus, a bit creamy.  T- Not as good as the nose. Citrus zest, coriander, clove, and light malts as a background are the main players here. Lingering clove/minty flavor.  M- Light medium body, somewhat watery on the finish. Smooth with a bit of a spritzy feel to it. Fairly high carbonation.  O- A nice hefeweizen. If I ever want a hefeweizen again, this is one I would go for, but I'm not a fan of the style...there are better refreshing styles out there in my opinion.

500 bottle into Weizen glass  A: Orangey golden, cloudy with a 3-finger foamy white head. Retains a finger all the way down, not too much lacing. Well carbonated.  S: Very fruity, with citrus notes dominating. Hint of banana. Also a hint of candy or bubblegum like smells. Hint of clove and spice too.  T: Fruity again - citrus at the front, quite sweet, nice subtle banana finish. Clove is there too. Muted bready, wheaty quality throughout. Banana aftertaste.  M: Light bodied but not watery, very fizzy on the tongue, extremely drinkable and refreshing.  Overall: Great Hefe-Weizen, would love to do side by side tests against my favourite of this style, Paulaner. Very tasty and refreshing, you could easy go through four or five of these without realizing. Would recommend.

A: A very cloudy light orange pour. Ridiculously huge and fluffy white head. Retention is top notch, it just won't fade, period. Takes several minutes before I can even take a sip. Leaves a thick layer of lacing all over the glass once it finally recedes.  S: Very fruity. Smells like bubblegum initially. I get some pear, lemons and maybe banana. Some wheat and a little bread in there too. Touch of spice, black pepper I'd say. Maybe a hint of grass somewhere in there. Very light, crisp and refreshing aroma.
