T: Lots of nice lemon, pear and banana. Nice bready yeast and some wheat to smooth it all out. Simple but tasty.  M: Light and crisp.  O: Perhaps the best Hefe I've had. Not overly complex or strong, just a great combination of balanced flavors. Drinkability is off the scale. Goes down so easily it's scary.

Two 12 oz. brown bottles poured into a large Hefeweisen glass brought home from my time in Germany.  First had this beer while stationed in Stuttgart and it convinced me forever not to drink BMC ever again.  Beautiful dirty orange with a sticky bright white lace.  Smells of malts and wheat with a hint of lemon, which many Germans add during the summer.  The taste is what beer is all about with wheat, barley and lemon. Crisp.  Best hefe on the planet -- Nectar of the Gods

To start the review, I will admit to being a bit biased by this beer. When I went through a German phase about 16-17 years ago, this stood out in my memory, and I was not disappointed when I picked this up again for the first time in years.  Pours almost clear straw and golden yellow, with a huge fluffy pure white head that leaves chunky lacing and caps the beer until I swallow the last of it.  Smell is lemony, yeasty, light bready malts.  Taste is clean dry malts, pure, a hint of the yeast, and some lemon in the aftertaste.  Feel is smooth, flowing, light bodied, and probably the easiest drinking beer ever!  While it doesn't have the punch of the bigger beers, this is just special. Balanced and drinkable. A classic beer from a brewery that has been doing it right for almost a millennium.  DOA

0.5l bottle poured into a Weihenstephaner glass. It pours a cloudy straw yellow with a dense white head that sticks around. Great lacing too. Absolutely gorgeous in it's own glass. It smells like wheat with malt, lemon and yeast notes and some hints of banana rounding it out. The taste is similar to the smell, wheat, yeast, banana, some spiciness, not bitter at all, super easy to drinkand a slightly dry finish. The super smooth, crisp and just perfect mouthfeel gives it an added dimension and it makes this beer just incredibly refreshing and drinkable.  This is beer that makes you happy. It's the perfect German beer, not super complex but never boring either. Easy to drink and perfect for drinking a lot of.

500 ml bottle poured into a pint glass  A: Hazy orange body with a vigorous head (from a very gentle pour) that slowly fades to, surprisingly, minimal lacing  S: The perfect hefe smell in my opinion, spices, yeast, hints of banana  T: Doesn't live up to the expectations surrounding my first experience with it, not that shocking no idea there was a beer out there like this experience, but still amazing nonetheless. Wonderful taste, reminiscent of the smell.  M: exceptionally smooth, mild carbonation  O: Brings back great memories of my time in Germany. An excellent hefe from an historic brewery. My only prior experience with Weihenstephan was their collaboration with Sam Adams to create Infinium, a less than promising first impression to be sure. I will definitely be coming back to this beer whenever I get the craving for a hefe.

A: Pours a hazy light golden color with a big head that fades slowly to ample lacing.  S: Aroma of spice, banana and vanilla with some malt sweetness in the background.  T: Taste of banana, spices and malt sweetness. No real bitterness and a clean finish.  F: Fairly medium body, smooth and refreshing.  O: A very enjoyable beer and an easy drinker. Probably my favorite "Hefe"

A - hazy yellow/orange body, 1finger of white head  S - Spices, clove, some banana.  T - like the nose. Clove, banana, some other milder spices.  M - thin. Very refreshing, clean carbonation.  Great beer. Perfect summer sipper. Need to pick up some bottles soon.

Pours hazy pale golden in body with frothy white head that leaves plenty of lacing. Beautiful lively looks. Aroma is yeasty, lemon cookies, faint vanilla, orange peel, clove, and banana. The epitome of the hefe. Lemon cookies, juicy orange, faint vanilla, banana esters, mild clove, mild hop character background, and smooth vanilla rides it out. Smooth mouthfeel with mild carbonation. A gorgeous display of what an iconic brewery can achieve.

16.9oz bottle poured into weizen glass.  A: Pours an opaque straw yellow with a 3 finger white head. Pretty sure the head could have lasted for 20min if I didnt drink first. Plenty of visible carbonation looks very inviting. Tons of lacing.  S: Yeast, banana, sweet malt. The only part this beer lacks.  T: Starts of with a smooth belgian yeast that blends into some nice wheat notes. Little hop in there at the end but quite faint and covered by the sweet malt.  M: Real good. Light, crisp carbonation is pleasant and drinkable. I dont think drinking beer gets any easier.  Overall a great go to beer especially on a warm day. One of the most refreshing and one I'd love to try fresher.

Lucky enough to have this one on tap at the Weihenstephan beer garden.  A - Cloudy golden color with a thick white head. The head retention is very good with nice lacing.  S - Nice balance between banana and clove esters. I feel that the Weinstephaner displays the clove notes more so than most others that i have tried.  T - Nice balance of notes from the yeast. Banana, clove, mixed with wheat. Very light hopping in balance with the malt.  M - Nice mouthfeel with high carbonation that sizzles on the tongue.  D - This is probably my favorite hefeweizen. A great beer overall especially if you be lucky enough to taste it fresh.

Finally I found this. I had heard so much about it here and elsewhere as the undisputed champ of hefes. So there it was at the bar out of nowhere and I pounced on it. Hmm. Well, it was fine, but... I don't get all the crazy praise for it. It was good but didn't do much more for me than other hefes, which I'm starting to have my doubts about. I'm wondering if the style is a narrow one, in which the differences between different offerings are small. If you served this to me I'd be happy enough, but rather than buy it again I'd rather explore other untried options. I will say it had a very pretty snowy white head. Seems like a good example of the style but I was let down that it wasn't crazy turbo good like the hype suggested. Or maybe I'm just not a hefe guy.

The appearance of this beer is a light, golden color with a little bit of cloudiness. The head poured thick (1 inch) and slowly turned thinner with moderate lacing.  The smell is really nice! Aromatic and powerful, it has a real nutty, wheaty smell followed by cloves.  The taste is like nothing else, literally! Lots of wheat and nut flavor, very natural! No bitterness and a hint of the sweet malt right before the carbonation takes over and bubbles on the tongue. The clove flavor is very present but balanced with the other flavors. Totally took me by surprise, great tasting beer!  The mouthfeel is crisp in the front and carbonated at the end, but a great carbonated. Not like the negative soda-like carbonation, but it is strong.  I am not a beer master, but I have had my fair share (much more than I have had a chance to review for this site) and the flavor of this beer is phenomenal. I bought it from Atlantic Liquors in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware (funny website, ridiculous store) not knowing what a reputation it had! Very surprised when I first tasted it then I came here to review and saw the scores it had received...what a great beer! A must try, no matter what your likes or experiences in the world of beer.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a curved pilsener glass- pours a hazy yellow orange color with a big puffy 2.5 finger head. Lasts a LONG time- keeps a half finger head the whole way through. Beautiful.  Smells delicious and rich- lots of wheat, a little bit of orange, good dose of lager yeast. Well balanced and enticing.  Taste is consistent with the smell- lots of bright rounded wheat, a bit of orange, maybe a bit of hop bitterness towards the end mixed with the yeast.  Mouthfeel is crisp= light body but very full flavored and nice medium carbonation (pour carefully). Great great beer- I'll be drinking this a lot this summer.

Pours a cloudy orange with a thick white head of tiny soapy bubbles.  Smells of banana, wheat, olive, nuts, and fresh fruit. A delightful bouquet with much complexity and subtlety.  A crisp sour sting of carbonation with some light lemony notes hits up front backed by banana notes giving way to an olive smoothness followed by a nutty round mouth feel with wheat notes. Slight fruit notes are detected in some of the bitterness, like the bite of raspberry without any of the sweetness. This is a delightfully complex beer perfect for a warm evening.

1 pt 0.9 fl oz brown glass bottle served in a weizen glass, reviewed live:  A - Pours a cloudy straw golden color with a fizzy and rocky white head that's five fingers tall. Retention is very good. Appealing but largely unremarkable.  S - Citrus esters and a bready yeast note dominate. Light spice, coriander and orange all come to mind. Mild to moderate strength and inviting.  T - The spice notes created by the yeast are awesome, and they blend wonderfully with the spicy wheat body. Light floral hops notes are present as well. It's a little mellow for my tastes, though I think it's probably ideal for the style. I get orange, clove, and coriander. It could benefit from a bit more depth, though whats there is very good.  M - Thick. It's carbonated well and light bodied.  D - You'd be hard pressed to find a better hefe. Incredibly easy drinking with good flavors. Not groundbreaking or entirely remarkable, but a very good beer.

A: Pale golden and very cloudy with sediment. Nice big fluffy white head that sticks around. Not much lacing.  S: Clean wheaty, malty aroma, very direct and pleasant.  T/M: Wheat, malts, banana, a hint of spiciness in the aftertaste. A little tingly due to all the carbonation.  O: The first weiss bier I've had, very tasty.

A very good overall Weizen with a good head and taste. The head is produced with very fine bubbles, a mark of a very good brew. A fair amount of hefe but not a lot. Not as spicy as Weizen in wester Bayern. So far the best one I have found that is available in the USA. I am having several right now.

Appearance - Pours a hazy, dark golden yellow with a think, frothy 3-finger white head. The head dissipates slowly, leaving behind a fine, consistent lace.  Smell - Beautiful rip banana, augmented by fair amount of clove notes. The aroma is intoxicating.  Taste - Begins with a prominent clove spice which lasts to the finish. Notes of banana, wheat and a bit of bubblegum-like yeast. Flavors do well to separate, each hitting their stride at different times. Finishes with the aforementioned clove, fading well into the aftertaste.  Mouthfeel - This has a light body, bit just a touch watery on the back end. Decently carbonated, leading to a crisp, sharp bite.  Overall - Oh goodness. This is one hell of a hefeweizen. I feel sorry for the people who get Widmer Hef and think that's the end all, be all of wheat beers. This is a world-class hef, and a benchmark for the style.

Bottle poured into a Weizen Glass. Bottle kept in fridge.  A- Pours a hazy golden yellow color, with lots of foamy white head that has some staying power. Lots of thick lacing staying on the glass while drinking. Lots of carbonation action going on. Tons of small bubbles rising to the top.  S- Yeast, some banana in the back. Very "spicy" aroma. Not Hot spicy, but like kitchen spices. Wheat is also present.  T- Strong German Flavor. Strong yeast, with the banana/clove taste. You can really taste the kitchen spices after swallowing. Complex but enjoyable.  M- Some what thick. It is thicker than I expected. I can describe it maybe as "creamy". Carbonation is not overwhelming. Feels full bodied, but on the low end of full.  O- Nice offering. I was drawn to this by their advertising as "The Worlds Oldest Brewery". Glad I picked some up, it was nice to try something out of my comfort zone. I was pleasantly surprised.

16.9 oz bottle poured into a (edited) wheat glass.  The beer produces a cloudy golden body with a brilliant white head of 2-2.5 fingers. Lots of visible carb going on.  The first whiff brought forth huge banana notes with the spicy clove and wheat right behind.  The spice flavor mixed with the tingling carbonation is so goood. Banana, bread, and a light citrus flavor round out the flavor profile along with a touch of sweetness.  This thing is smooth with medium carbonation and a medium body.  I am looking forward to more of these Bad Boys as Spring springs.

Poured into 20oz mug. Excellent smell of a true German Hefe. Look golden color with a nice look to its body. Taste, authentic German taste to it. Only prefer german hefes, true taste. This hefe is high quality and can be find easily in my neck of the woods, pdx area. Try this hefe & look to compare others to it... A-

This beer is pure magic, making me ashamed that it took me so long to try it.  Poured into a pint glass, the beer gave a lemon aroma. I was expecting a sweeter aroma for a hefeweiss, so a tart aroma was somewhat of a surprise. For a hefeweiss, it radiated the expected golden staw color while producing the expected white head. The initial taste makes very apparent an appealing banana yeast flavor. It is sweet, but not overpoweringly sweet. The carbonation could be described as sharp, perhaps even aggressive. It brought to mind the bubbles of champagne. The bubbles nicely sweet away the initial taste to reveal the next level. The aftertaste brought a mild honey flavor with a hint of the spiciness of pepper.  This is one highly regarded beer that is easily available to most people. The price of a bottle makes it look even better compared to a lot of beers.

Poured into a small Weissbier glass. Slightly, and i mean slightly, cloudy yellow body. Medium bodied white head.  The smell wasnt what I remembered. Nice clove presence, with hints of banana in the background. Then there was a pervasive wheat twang that I didnt like all too much.  The taste is dominated by clove all the way. Full body feel from the yeast, but its really all a facade. The mainly clove followed by hints of banana subside, and leave all the clean finish to come through.  Theres a reason Weihenstephan is the king of Hefeweizens.

Hazy golden orange colour, 3 fingers of white head, good lacing going down the glass. Smell is yeasty, banana, clove and spicy notes, some bubble gum and malt. Taste has lots of banana, crisp crakery malt, wheaty/yeasty flavours, spicy flavours, clove, vanilla and finishes a little sweet. Med-high carbonation, full feel, medium-full body. I could drink this all day long, textbook hefe, when I'm in the mood for the style one of these is certainly in order.

12oz bottle into tulip snifter.  Pours a bright, hazy golden yellow with a thick, foamy white head.  The aroma and taste are a very nice blend of banana and clove.  A medium body, with foamy carbonation.  A very well done hefeweizen, definitely a classic.

Straw yellow with a slight haze. Out of control head on pour, with lots of lacing as you drink. Really pleasant nose. Perfumy, estery, fruity aromas.  At first sip I want to just keep gulping it down! Definitely some banana. Peppery flavors, too. Finishes with a perfect dryness, yet leaves a hint of sweetness and tartness on the tongue. Complex aftertaste with hints of yeast as well.  Overall: A!

Poured from a pint bottle into a Samuel Adams Alpine Spring glass.  A - Tons of head, 3 fingers of white head. Cloudy straw colored.  S - Banana, yeast, cloves, wheat  T - Tons of flavor, like banana bread with that good bubblegum taste, complex yet easy to drink  M - Feels pretty creamy and light  O - Utterly drinkable and quality brew. Truly a remarkable beer.

Taste - Franziskaner is my favorite Hefeweizen. This? Is almost identical, but two things make it different. One, is that its much more flavorful. Franziskaner is a little lighter in body comparably. Second, is that, to me, if I let it sit on my palate, it brought forth the banana note. That was really kind of cool how the flavor became more pronounced.  Overall - Its all about preference. This has all the characteristics of a great hefeweizen, its still relatively easy-drinking; but its a bit more fuller and bolder in taste, and that makes this great in its own way. You won't be disappointed here.

Pour = super hazy gold/orange. Bubbles everywhere just racing off the bottom of the glass. About a four finger, soft billowy head  Smell = bananas, oranges, cloves, a hint of lemon. A little bit of biscuity yeast. In one word, refreshing  Taste = alot like the nose , but it hits you in waves as it spreads on the tongue. First I get the spicy cloves, then the tangy orange and lemon and am left with the ripe sweet banana flavor.  Probably the best, purest, most balanced Hefeweizen I have ever had.

Appearance: Holy bountiful white heads! I could just keep pouring and pouring the foam above the glass. It is a very cloudy yellow to gold (more yellow towards the bottom and gold in the middle top).  Smell: Banana-y bread. Also some clove as I would expect, and even the possibility of a rose smell among others (my nose isn't the best however). Awesome.  Taste: Crisp wheat flavors. Very bready and malty with banana and clove flavors that do not overwhelm as they do in so many others in the style. There are also citrus notes and just the slightest tinge of tanginess. The great balance in this makes it superior to any Hefeweizen I have ever had and probably will ever have.  Mouthfeel: Smooth and kind of thin. Mouth coating with a thick layer of amazing crispness. Again, a great part of a great beer.  Overall: This is a stellar beer that surpasses anything I have had in the style and maybe from the country itself. Not my favorite beer ever, but within its style, I see no way that they could improve it.

Popping off the cap a foam head is slowly pushing out. Smells of banana. Poured into a Pilsner glass. Tastes of banana and there's something else in the mix, maybe sweetcorn. Soft malty aftertaste. Took a big manly gulp and got a momentary wash of cloves. Slightly champagney, even reminiscent of Duvel. Fantastic head retention. Very lively on the tongue, lovely.  Overall: This got me onto Weissbiers but I've tried loads since then and this is pretty unremarkable compared to a lot of others. In my opinion it's one of the most overrated beers on BA.

Bought this last night from Tanakaya in Mejiro, Tokyo. Excited about this one because I saw it has the highest ranking for hefes here on BA. DID NOT DISAPPOINT! Poured it into a new Paulaner hefe glass (also purchased at Tanakaya), and enjoyed enjoyed enjoyed! The head on this is ridiculously amazing, delicious and long-lasting, lacing the glass like a frappe. Loved watching all the particles float around in the glass, heightening the smell of orange and wheat and the taste of the same. The only thing I could ask for is a bit thicker of a brew just to give my tongue something else to play with. Other than that, this is the best hefe I have ever had, and especially for the price (relatively cheap), I will be a fan of this for life! GET IT!

Wait...can it be? Do you hear that?  It's the sound of angels singing in German.  It pours into my Weissbeir Glass with a thud. A small Bavarian farmer fell into it, and threw loaves of bread at my tongue. The beer is hearty, clove like, and packed with yeasty banana effervescence. Next time, I'm pouring this over my ice cream. It's the real deal.  Any product that has been in production for over 500 years doesn't need a review. This beer has achieved more then you and I combined.  Hier ist Götter Bier, Prost!

This pours a cloudy gold color with two finger width of off-white fluffy head that lingers and laces extremely well. Right on top I get clove, banana, and great floral aroma. great taste that just cleans you palate with every drink great subtle hint of all the flavors from the nose then I pick up a great bready flavor along with a wheat taste that comes with every beer in this style. This is medium bodied with medium to high amount of carbonation but nothing out of line with the style. This is the pinnacle of this style all other hefe's get compared to this, this beer is the gold standard of Hefe's.

Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbier is a textbook example of a classic Hef that achieves the pinnacle of the style. Poured into a belgian hefeweissbier glass, the beer stands tall with a pure white, soft bubbly foam head that tantalizes you to take a sip. Upon first sip, one instantly recognizes that hearty wheat flavor, combined with a comfortable, relaxed, light body mouth feel that is extremely satisfying. After a few sips one begins to appreciate the subtle complexity of the beer, with orange and light citrus hints as well as the classic German yeasty-malty flavor. Perfect beer with a light meal or on it's own, one never tires of a cold Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbier.

Enjoyed in a weizen glass  A: Pours a slightly hazy yellowish golden color that is nice and bright and has a ton of carbonation bubbles, pours with three fingers of pure white head that lingers for a very very long time (im actually sitting here waiting for the head to drop back down to the level of the top of the glass so that i can take a sip) and is very fine bubbled, leaves a ton of thin lacing S: really nice clean wheat scent, nice bready warmth and depth, a very slight citrus note evens it out at the end T: well, shes delicious, as delicious as everyone says? quite possibly, begins nice and bready then kicks in with a nice citrus note, bready taste lingers on the palate long afterwards M: smooth and bright, medium carbonation, leaves the mouth feeling clean, nice O: its one hell of a beer, quite possibly the best for the style, very highly drinkable and delicious

nobody on this site seams to review a beer and give it there perfect rating. I have tried many different Hefeweisse biers for about the last 6 years as well as my own and have found that this example is the best. it is said that this brewery has the earliest established date for brewing a wheat beer. however, this does not mean that all others should be judged by this breweries product. that said, this beer displays all of the characteristics of a bavarian wheat beer. the appearance after pouring the beer and its sediment is a hazy light yellow with a full white h ead. the head or lacing, permeates through out the drinking of the beer. smell is of musty bubble gum (banana and clove) taste is both banana and clove and earthy. it has a slight lean towards the bitterness of earthy hops and yeast than most, but in my opinion is the epitomy of german weisse bier.

Poured from a 500 ml. bottle into a Duvel Belgian Tulip glass.  Appearance: A semi-aggressive pour yielded a fluffy off-white 2” head, reducing to a thin ring. Lacing was clearly present, sticking to the side of my glass indicating the original head height. This beer poured golden yellow in color with definitive murkiness to it.  Smell: The classic Hefeweizen banana and yeasty aroma shines through, with a zesty citrus wheat finish. Clove is also present with a honey-like sweetness.  Taste: I can see why this beer rates so high among the Hefeweizens on the market. Banana dominates, with spicy wheat malts, honey, coriander, cloves and hint of lemon zing too. What a wonderful combination of flavors on the palate.  Mouthfeel: Light to moderate body with lively carbonation makes this an easy drinking beer. Very smooth, creamy and balanced on the tongue.  Overall: Outstanding Hefeweizen in every single category. This beer, by far, ranks up there at the top of its class. At only 5.4% ABV, this makes for the perfect flavorful all-year-round session beer. I can imagine this being quite the quencher during the summer months but if I’m being totally honest, I’m enjoying the heck out of this in the middle of February. I'm glad I committed to buying a few bottles of this. Well done Weihenstephaner, well done…

A: Wow. Lucius creamy 2 finger white head. Small bubbles lead to an amazing texture on the head. Hazy, yeast driven look. Straw to golden in color.  S: German phenols. Banana and clove but without the Belgian additions of strength. I love how subtle the German strain is in comparison. Also, this beer has a great bready quality to it.  T: Rich creamy head to a bread malt backbone that is sweet as well as clovey. I enjoy the banana esters as well as the beer finishes. I am such a fan of the tastes as they are balances and well thought out.  M: Perfect to style. Medium bodied. But light in complexity. Crisp enough to fend of stylish fish dishes but delicate enough to be overpowered with spices.  O: This is another fantastic German Wit. I am biased because this is one of my favorite styles but this is a great drinking beer. The German subtitles and balance really make me excited in comparison to the Belgian strength and extremes. I align more so with balances and crisp flavor than over the top yeast attributes.

Poured into a classic Hef glass. Always a sexy beer when poured in the proper wear. Hazy golden orange with a giant pillowy head Bananas, cloves in the nose. Banana bread, cloves, sweet fruity esters with a very light hop finish. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Fluffy and drinkable. This is THE Hef. This is the standard that everything else is compared to and often fails.

I've drink this brew several times. Half liter bottles poured into a HefeWeizen glass. -Translucid dark yellow/pale Orange colour. -Banana and Floral smell. -Archetypical HefeWeizen taste. -Watery feel. Extremely easy to drink.  Superb HefeWeizen.

Appearance: The beer pours a beautiful golden body with a huge head of carbonation. A similar amount of retention is rarely seen. This is a beautiful beer.  Smell: Clove, banana, wheat, coriander, and a small hint of lemon juice can be detected. The clove aroma seems to grow stronger as the beer warms.  Taste: It is nearly the same as the smell advertised; a near perfect balance of sweet fruit, spice, and wheat is achieved.  Mouth feel: It is light bodied with an intense amount of carbonation. In other words, incredibly refreshing.  Overall: I thought for sure this beer was over-hyped when buying it. I was dead wrong. This beer looks great, smells great, feels great, and establishes an almost unrivaled balance.

500ml bottle into Augustiner weizen glass, no BB  Pours with a huge fluffy white head, allow some head space, swirl the final bit and dump in the yeast. Slightly clear straw yellow gets hit with the yeast and clouds up nicely, final color is a hazy yellow/orange. Head goes down to a skim a bit too quickly to be perfect. Smell is pure weizen yeast: banana, cloves and some dry wheat. Man is this beer aromatic. Taste has tons of yeast complexity and some clove spiciness, hint of sweet from the malt. Mouthfeel has some dryness due to the wheat, light bodied and very high carb, carb even teases the mouth.  Hands down the best hefeweizen, the Germans invented the style and they sure do know how to make em. The only American hefe that comes close is SN's Kellerweiss. Light bodied and full of flavor with none of the off tastes that inferior beers of the style so often have. I feel pity for the person who lets blue moon be the beginning and end of their foray into wheat beers. If the head had held up better and the smells had hit harder this would be a perfect beer. I long for the day I can try this one fresh at the brewery.

A - Pours clear, golden yellow. A massive 3 finger frothy white head forms and stays around a bit before settling down to a nice rim of white. Awesome spotty lacing.  S - Banana, clove, slight coriander, yeast and a bit of malt. Really great smelling.  T - Taste follows the nose, with a bit more of the malt showing up. Really well balanced between the fruit and malt.  M - Light bodied and crisp, with perfect carbonation.  O - I can see why this is considered the gold standard for Hefe's. It really is an awesome beer.

A: Cloudy golden hue, with a touch of orange. Head is massive and foamy, and lingers a LONG time. Lacing is good.  S: Perfect for a Hefeweizen! Wheat, citrus, pepper, and a little banana. I could keep sniffing this all day, but for the urge to drink.  T: Wheat is there, but no malty sweetness. A little citrus tartness, but less than the smell would indicate. The bitterness in the finish was potent, but not in a bad way.  M: A bit dry, with average carbonation for the style.  O: Very good. I can see why the brewery has been around for nearly a thousand years. I was a little disappointed that the taste didn't live up to the aroma. I'd drink another anytime, but given the choice, I'd go with Paulaner for a Hefewiezen.  On a side note, it's interesting that this brewer of a wheat beer makes the claim, "brewed under the purity law of 1516" when wheat was specifically forbidden by that law (but I guess it sounds better for marketing than saying, "brewed under the provisional German beer law of 1993")

A beer that I've claimed over the past few years as one of my top ten favorites, tonight's beer is the Weihenstephaner Hefe Weissbier. Brewed in Bavaria, Germany, Weihenstephan's label states that it's the oldest brewery in the world. Records date back to the year 768 with documents mentioning a hop garden, but the brewery was officially licensed in 1040.  The 17oz bottle pours at a clear burnt-amber color, with a nice thick ivory white foam on top. The foam lingers for several minutes, and leaves behind a mild lacing as it recedes. The aromas are bright and distinct, with plenty of lemon, orange peel, banana, and spices. I absolutely love the aromas on this little Hefeweiss!  On the palate, the Weihenstephaner is flavorful and complex, yet so incredible easy to drink! The citrus and banana is right up front in my mouth, but not far behind is the spice and just a touch of alcohol. This is an absolutely delicious brew that I highly recommend for anyone who ever considered those mediocre mass-produced imitations.

A-light golden opaque color with a white head and some lacing  S-bananas and spices and some malty sweetness  T-citrus and banana with nice malt and hint of sweetness, complex blend of flavors  F-light body with nice carbonation, crisp yet smooth  O-a delicious and complex beer with great balance

500 ml bottle poured into pilsener glass. Did not see date on bottle. It's possible this is old, since it's from a shop without a particularly high rate of turnover.  Pours a slightly hazy straw color, with an enormous amount of white head. Seriously, I poured down the side of the glass slowly, and it's still about 90% head to start off. It takes some time to come down enough to add more beer, and remain highly effervescent. Leaves some slight lacing on the side of the glass, and a few mm of head is left on the surface.  Smells like a classic hefe. Not as much banana as others. Mostly yeast, with some citrus and wheat with only a hint of cloves.  The taste mirrors the smell very closely - very yeasty. The wheat is only in the aftertaste, it seems. While it's very good, and has good balance overall, I'd like a little more banana and a little less yeast.  Medium body and quite creamy from the carbonation. Light enough to be very refreshing, but not special.  Overall it's a very good hefe. I'm not sure I would consider it the 44th best beer in the world, and in the style I like Dry Dock Hefe more. I would like to try it again with a bottle I know is fresh.

Poured into a 312 Weizen Glass.  A: This Hefe pours a wonderful golden with an enormous frothy white head. There is a wonderful amount of retention in this head and the lacing is remarkable.  S: I adore the Banana smell, hint of cloves, and a hint of spice of some sort. This is what I think of when I think Hefeweizens.  T: This is an interesting and complex taste, unlike the nose, on my first sip the cloves invite me in then tempt me with a small amount of banana flavor and then more cloves, and finishes with a bready malt flavor that makes you wanting more.  M: This is a lighter beer with a nice dry finish that leaves you wanting more , incredibly smooth, a lovely beer.  O: The fact that I can get this beer locally for less than $2.50 will lead me to have it more and more often. While this is rated as the best Hefe, I would rank it Number 2 behind Dancing Man by New Glarus, which has a more prominent Banana flavor and more subtle clove flavor. i would recommend this Beer to everyone, Well Done as One would expect from the Worlds oldest brewery.

A: Pours a hazy straw/gold with a massive, creamy, smooth head that dissipates extremely slow. Heavy carbonation.  N: Wheat, banana and light notes of clove and lemon.  T: Banana, wheat and faint lemon upfront followed by hints of strawberry. Finishes with faint notes of clove and apricot.  M: Medium-full bodied, crisp, smooth, clean and refreshing.  O: This is the best Hefeweizen I've ever had. Very subtle and easy to drink. I've put it off for a long time because I'm not a fan of wheat beers but this is fantastic! It is indeed world class.

Poured into a 500ml weihenstephan weizen glass.  A- cloudy golden yellow, about 2 inches of fluffy white head that takes ages to subside with a nice lacing. pretty much perfect.  S- Lots of clove and peppery spice straight up, yeastiness, banana, touch of sweetness, citrus on the end. each flavor strong, and each moving into the other very well  T- straight up, a touch of malts, but then banana, clove, spice, pepper, yeast, more citrus than on the nose, rounding everything out very well. delicious.  M- lighter to mid-bodied, a spritzy carbonation, nice length. nice feel.  O- looks amazing, smells and tastes great, mouthfeel is the one weakness but its still really good. great beer. love it

Note: On tap at the peculier pub. NYC  A: Corn yellow with a paper white, long lasting head. Hazy sediment.  S: Corriander, nutmeg, clove, wheat and citrus.  T: First notes are of distinct german and belgian spices, such as corriander, nutmeg, and lemon zest. Wheat and pilsner malt notes with a noble hops bitterness. Slight clove and banana. Dry aftertaste.  M. light to medium body, and low carbonation. Slightly bitter.  O: The default top tier example of a German Hefe.

Bottle gifted by Huhzubendah, Thanks Matt  Pours a light gold color with a perfect two finger white head. Great lacing, and great carbonation. Hazy in appearance. The nose is amazing, wheat, yeast, lemon, and malt. Taste follows the nose profile. Feel is just about perfect... Sweet, with a perfect malt backbone and refreshing finish. There's a reason this is #1 beer in style.. It doesn't get any better than this for a hefeweizen. Cheers.

a: perfect gold, hazy from the yeast  s: smells of really nice yeast, and wheat. A little bit of alcohol breathes through if you keep sniffing. Perfumy.  t: Nice and crisp. The carbonation is perfect and so is the taste. Not too much yeast and the sweetness and the wheat is perfectly balanced.  o: Very nice beer. I'd buy it again.

Weihenstephaner has a long history of brewing great beers, and it definitely shows here...  A: This beer poured a cloudy golden typical of a good well-made hefe-weizen with little to no head but with a good amount of carbonation flowing through after the pour.  S: Very citrusy, definite lemon/orange scents strike right away with a nice malty sweetness and some slightly yeasty smells lingering in the background.  T: Right away the citrus that was apparent in the aroma strikes and gives a nice refreshing flavor, followed by some malty sweetness to balance the zest. Again following the aroma, with a nice yeasty finish and a hint of hoppy bitterness.  M: Very refreshing flavor just as hefe's should have. Coats the mouth well without being too thick and has a nice bubbly carbonation that gives a nice finish.  Overall I really enjoyed this beer and have drank many since my original tasting. Definitely a must drink as a great cornerstone of the world's oldest brewery!

Look: Yellowish orange in color with a 1.5 inch white head and great retention with some spotty lacing  Smell: Wheat citrus and a bit of funk  Taste: The beer starts off with a bright crisp citrus character and is backed up by some banana and clove notes and finishes with a touch of wheat and spice  Mouthfeel: Thin body and ample carbonation  Overall: This is hands down the best example of the style I have ever had and per style is almost perfect. I would have liked a bit more on the nose but I am just nit picking at this point

A: Bottle poured into pint glass. Radiant (that's the best word to describe it), cloudy orangey gold color with a towering white head that won't go away. Leaves lacing all over the glass. Dude.  S: Smells fruity with some banana and citrus, along with the spiciness from the yeast that suggests clove and other baking spices.  T: Banana, clove, spice, light citrus. Tastes exactly as a hefewiezen should.  M: Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, with a lot of tiny bubbles hitting the tongue.  O: I can see why this is considered the best hefeweizen on the face of the Earth. Incredible.

If you want an archetype of the hefeweissen style, this is it. Pours a beautiful deep yellow gold color that leaves a nice two finger white head that slowly recedes and leaves plenty of lacing. Smells of wheat, banana, citrus. Taste is on point for a hefe; nicely balanced wheat, citrus, banana, and a light bitterness at the end. Everything about this beer in the taste department is done brilliantly. Mouthfeel is good, fairly light overall and easy to drink a pint or two. All in all, if you want a good hefe, this is the one to go to.

pours a nice golden color, huge white frothy head with great retention and lacing  wheat, bananas, citrus/orange, bready, some mild spice great nose very inviting  and wow great flavor, follows the nose. bready, bananas are really present. notes of citrus/orange.  mouthfeel is great. light bodied high carbonation. almost fluffy like your drinking a cloud, and really easy to put it down.  overall great beer so worth the price (under $4) and could drink it anytime

A - Pours a hazy orange with a two and a half finger white head with great retention and good lacing.  S - I don't know why but when I first opened the bottle I got a whiff of plums, once poured a strong sweet smell of bananas and light citrus the smells are very prominent and pleasant.  T - Much like the smell bananas, citrus, malts and yeast, a great crisp refreshing taste.  M - Medium bodied, very smooth with the perfect amount of carbonation it doesn't get any better then this.

Its about time I sit down with one of these and enjoy the experience out loud. This looks like a beer should look when poured. hazy straw colored, with a solid 2 finger head that leaves plenty of lacing and carbonation filling the glass. its smells of citrus and funk and makes your mouth water. The wheat flavor is up front with good funk finishing up with a crisp refeshing mouthfeel and a bit floral at the end. This is well done and could stand up nexrt to just about anythings the state try and produce in this wheat variety. Bravo German brew dudes.

Lovely malted wheat character accented with citrus and nutty yeast in the backround. Also, a subtle hint of clove plays its own subtle tune to round off this quartet of flavor. Just the right amount of carbonation with a very clean balanced alcohol finish. All in all, the beer is the prototype for other Hefeweizen makers to follow. This said, one should expect no less from a beer traditions that dates back to 1040. Enjoy!!  Glass = Tulip.  Drink Temp. = 48 F.  Serving = 16.9 oz Bottle.

500ml poured into a tulip. pours a hazy, brilliant straw-yellow. insane head, frothy, billowing for days. i actually only drank half the bottle, forgot to cap it in the fridge, still poured to a 1/2 head 2 days later! ridiculous lacing of course.  smell - bananas, cloves, a bit of citrus. taste follows - more cloves and spiciness, bubblegum, and a perfect tang on the back end.  easy to see why it's world class. exceptional example of the style.

11.2oz bottle poured into a weizen glass A: Hazy golden-orange; even a slow pour forms an incredibly thick head that takes a while to settle S: Incredibly complex with coriander/clove, wheat, orange, bubblegum, banana. Just wonderful to smell. T: Virtually identical to the smell, with spice, wheat, banana bread. Only slight complaint is a short finish. M: A bit watery, but medium-bodied and pleasant overall. O: Very enjoyable and well-made; a world-class beer.

500 ml bottle. Pours slightly hazy golden straw color with a huge 3 finger dense white head with incredible retention that reduces to a cap that stays for the remainder of the glass. Thick lacing clings around the glass as well, incredible. Aromas of big banana, clove, bubblegum, pepper, lemon, and spicy yeast. Fantastic aromas here with great balance and strength. Taste of big clove, pepper, banana, bubblegum, lemon, bread, and spicy yeast. Light bitterness on the finish that lingers with citrus, pepper, banana, and spices for a bit. Extremely smooth and slightly creamy medium sized body. Fairly lively carbonation that dies down as I make my way through the glass. Extremely well balanced with the flavor profile as well. Overall this is an absolutely incredible wheat beer; and the definition of a hefeweizen in my opinion. I will keep coming back to this one at only $3 for a half liter at the store.

This was the first top 100 beer I ever sampled. Half-liter bottle.  Light cloudiness, but transparent gold to golden-orange. Towering 7 finger thick white head off the first pour. It settled slowly, allowing the beer to warm. Some of the thickest lacing I've ever seen. Carbonation bubbles rise non-stop throughout the beer.  Aroma of sweet banana, citrus and spice (heavy on the clove). Toasted wheat.  Taste of banana and cloves with tart citrus and light toasted malt. Light earthiness.  Rather thick, but silky smooth and creamy. Peppery with warmth in the throat. lightly cloying.  Wonderful, quite a treat.

Weihenstephaner Hefe Weissbier has a very thick, white, pillowy head and a hazy, yellow-golden appearance, with lots of streaming bubbles, some lace, and little light-brown yeast chunks floating about. The aroma is faint, but one can just detect water and a little bread. Taste is of banana, white wheat bread, coriander or cloves (hard to say which), and water, plus, maybe cinnamon. The body is on the watery side, and Weihenstephaner Hefe Weissbier finishes easy-drinking and wet. Overall, this is a good beer, but, with it’s spicy aspects, I would not want to have it with a meal.  RJT.

Another one bought at Pinkies San Angelo - saw the label for "the world's oldest" but several seem to claim that title. So I decided to see how an ancient beer has stood up to the test of time.  Appearance - A beautiful amber/brown color. Very carbonated and a great mix of browns.  Smell - A tart almost crisp smell. Some may find it too tart, but excellent along with the taste  Taste - Wheaty with a mix of fruit. The main one I pick up is fresh peaches and a slice of pear. Now this isn't a fruity beer, but has a great fruit finish.  Mouthfeel - Carbonation Perfection!  Overall - a great evening beer that should be enjoyed often.

Serving Type - Bottle  Appearance - Light golden wheat tan, monster foamy 3+ inch head with tons of lacing  Smell - Wheat, yeast, lemon, grassy, floral hops, orange, spices, banana and pear.  Taste - Very smooth wheat up front. Banana is a main flavor, along with some orange and lemon. Spices along with the hops are light, crisp and very well balanced with each wheaty, yeasty drink. No alcohol in the taste.  Mouthfeel - Light, refreshing and easy on whole mouth. Wheat and sweet lemon and banana coats tounge and palette leaving it refreshed and unscarred. Aftertaste is and floral.  Overall - Perfect example of the style, very easy to drink, smooth, tasty and light. Perfect for a summer drink, or with some meat feature dishes, this is bout as good as it gets for hefeweizen.

Appearance: It pours a very cloudy golden color with a head that is two fingers tall. The head retentention is not bad. Spotty lacing is left behind as the head thins out.  Aroma: Notes of clove, banana, spicy floral hop. A little bit of butteryness in the nose. In the way back the is a wisp of butterscotch in the nose.  Taste: Up front is a light crisp mouthfeel. At the begining are notes of banana, clove. In the middle are wisps of citrus. Towards the end is twinge of lemon zest and a nice dry crisp finish.  Notes: Dam this is an amazing Hefeweizen quite possibly the best Hefe I have ever had. Cheers.

On tap at the Braustuberl Weihenstephaner, Freising, so shouldn't come any fresher than this !  Poured into the appropriate 0.3l glass with a couple of fingers head  A real treat of a hefeweiss ! You can tell they've been dabbling in the field for 971 years, I think they've cracked it !!!  Cloudy dark yellow in colour (there wasn't much lighting in the cellar room we were in, so difficult to be precise on this one!)  Full of flavour namely a hint of banana with cloves and other spices, truly well balanced beer of this style  The smells largely matched the taste to save repetition  The mouthfeel did it for me, silky smooth and my palate begged for more, lacing remained throughout my drinking experience  Wunderbar !!!

From twelve ounce bottle coded 5211.  Pours a hazy, golden/lemon yellow with nice tan head. Head does not last long and lacing is spotty. Aroma is sweet grass and malt. Taste is incredibly smooth and refreshing. Citrusy notes. Amusing aftertaste, tingly carbonation.

Style: Hefeweizen  Color: Blonde with a golden hue SRM: 5-6 Clarity: Cloudy Head: Rich lacy white foam (creamy, but firm) Bubbles: Champagne, fine and abundant Effervescence: Slow  Nose: Banana, cloves and wheat. Floral and citrusy.  Flavour: Banana, cloves and sweet apple-like fermented fruit. Fruity bubblegum and a hint of spicy flavours.  Body: Medium bodied with a creamy texture.  Aftertaste: Light and refreshing. Lively carbonation, Medium to short finish.  Overall: Served at 4 º–6 ºC. It is one of the greatest wheat beers.

Appearance: Orange-yellow glowing body. Unfiltered. Foamy egg-white head with long lasting retention and lace all over the glass.  Smell: Wheat. Fabulous estery divinity. Bananas, citrus especially lemon and even orange. Bubblegum and coconut.  Taste: Dry grainy fruity and floral blend of wheat and nice noble hops. Slight bitterness.  Mouthfeel: Cooling and refreshing. Wondefully balanced example of the style. Light spritzer body. Stays tasty even as it warms.  Overall: An amazing example of the style. I find few flaws with this beer. The price is good. A world classic. I wish it was more widely available. I think everyone would drink this.

Cloudy orange and yellow brew with thick white head.. retention is strong, lacing is sturdy like jello...  wheat, sweet malts, orange peel, lemon, banana, pear in the nose  taste like the perfect hefeweizen... full bodied, everything you smell you taste, perfect mouthfeel, carbonation is there but not distracting...  i want some german food, sausage, mashed potatoes, white asparagus... it's so damn good, perfect for the style...

Served at a warm temperature with a nice foamy, light tan head and a little lace. Color is a cloudy brown amber. Aroma is heavy malt, raisins, figs, dates, hint of molasses. Flavor is like nose, malt sweetness is on top, followed with the dark ripe fruit and carbonics. Body is perfect, ditto carbonation. Finish is like flavor, fairly long and balanced.

Poured from a bottle into a Pilsener glass.  Look - light amber color, clear, with good carbonation and about three fingers' worth of off-tan colored foam that dissipates fairly slowly.  Smell - very sweet and malty, with not much of a hop presence, but very much of a wheat-like presence.  Taste - right away the wheat makes itself known. It very much does indeed remind me of Bavarian beers in general. The banana flavor is pretty prominent. Quite well on the sweet side, with no bitterness.  Mouthfeel - pretty well balanced, but leans a little more on the watery side.  Overall - Not a bad tasting brew at all, and it's a good representative of the style.

A: Oh dear God the head of this beer is massive. The head fades over time, but its like a 5 finger head at first. The beer is a nice golden with a slight cloudiness.  S: The beer has a strong tangerine smell with some sweet malt and banana. Not much else after that, but it really doesnt need much else. It smells awesome.  T: I am getting a bit of grain and some weird hay flavor. I am also getting lemon and banana.  M: The beer is very smooth and has a nice fluffy feel. I think this is one of the better feeling beers.  O: I have never really cared for Hefeweizens, but man this beer is good.

Been saving this for Thanksgiving dinner and it was well worth the wait. Poured a beautiful dark honey/golden straw with plenty of haze and a 3 finger pillow white head that faded to 1 finger thorughout the beer. Lacing was spectacular and when poured into a weizen glass it stands out. Smell was very complex with notes of banana, cloves, lemon and bread. Not too strong, but adequate. Taste was fantastic. Follows the nose pretty close, but adds a hint of spices to balance the citrus/fruit on the front end. Classic for the style and spot on. Feel was a good bit of carbonation with a dry ending. Not too watery, but not overpowering. Overall- Not sure I can come up with anything new to say about this that hasn't already been said. This is the gold standard of a Hefeweizen IMO and easily in my top 5 all time brews. While I think nothing is perfect, this comes damn close. Complex/Full taste, great aromas, beautiful balance and a great top off to Thanksgiving Dinner. Will be gettting more of this for next summer- Outstanding!

500mL bottled (code 6111) poured into a weizen glass. Hazy straw color w/ a nice fluffy white head, great carbonation.  Aroma is banana, clove, pepper, and spice.  Taste is banana, clove/spice, and lemon.  Utterly smooth, mellow, and drinkable. A classic version of the style.

Poured from an undated 330ml bottle into a pint glass  A: Pours a hazy, golden honey color with a big, pillow head. Settles in the glass looking like cloudy, unfiltered goodness topped by a crown of foamy head. Very attractive.  S: Spicy, medicinal notes grace the nose with heaps of clove and banana. The aroma is rather pronounced and carries pretty far from the glass.  T: This beer nails the art of the hefeweizen with perfect form. Starts with assertive, yeasty spiciness dashed with generous amounts of well balanced clove notes and touches of banana bread. Finishes very clean, much like eating a sliver of ginger root. Intensely refreshing - I couldn't ask for more.  M: Prickly carbonation, lighter bodied, with a well-executed semi-dry finish. Rather slick on the palate going down, leaves a pleasant mark as the flavors flee the tongue.  O: What hasn't already been said about this beer? It is simply the standard by I believe all other hefeweizens should be judged.

Just got back from Iraq and wanted to start myself off with a good Hefe so knowing Weihenstephaner to be pretty damn good, i selected this bad boy as my first beer, straight out of the sandbox. That being said:  A: I always love the crisp look of this beer, its golden aura just stands light years away from other "Yellow Water" beers (i.e.: Budweiser, Miller, etc). The head...well, it just doesnt want to go away. It is creamy, thick and most of all likes hanging around. Threw this one into a weizen glass and the head combined with the pale, crisp color and the crazy storm of carbonation (at the onset anyway) just pales in comparison to most other Hefe's. The only downside is that you can just see the bubbles start dying or slowing down and its just...sad.  S: citrusy, fruity, like it should pretty much lol. Good smell  T: great taste, its refreshing, cleanses the palate and just prepares you for another sip. Its as if this just gets better after every sip. Or it could be that i'm biased since its my first one for the past year and its just delicious :)  M: Invigorating and cleansing. You can just imagine eating some sort of flavorful dish and this would be the type of beer that just washes the taste away and leaves your tastebuds awaiting more.  O: Solid, Solid beer. I cant go as far as saying that i love it, as I am a Dubbel kinda guy, but this is just a great, overall beer. Anytime i have company over, i get this, or if its a BYOB thing (so i dont show up others by coming in with a corked bottle of some Trappist and looking like a snobby, a-hole) but i'll bring this. Its a great beer and trying to pronounce the name is always a good conversation starter :)

Served cold into a large tulip glass.  It has a very hazy golden color with thick, creamy, lacy head.  Aroma is fruity, spicy, and nutty.  Flavor is mild but full of depth and character. Banana, bubblegum, and clove all come forward.  Mouthfeel is wonderful on tap. Smooth, light, and creamy.  Overall a great beer that is possibly even better served on tap.

Poured from a 500ml bottle into a pint glass.  A: Clear gold/orange with lots of carbonation bubbles and a 1 finger foamy rocky head.  S: Banana bread and cloves make up the nose.  T: Liquid gold! Clean wheat taste with Belgian yeasts apparent. Banana flavor with spices throughout.  M: Creamy into a foamy mouth thanks to the medium carbonation.  O: This is hands down the most balanced and flavorful hefeweizen I've ever had. I'll be picking this up alternating with Sam Smiths Oatmeal Stout for a low alcohol go to when I have to drive.

Poured from a 11.2oz bottle into a weissbier glass. Generous 3" creamy head (or more!) which lingers for a while. Typical blonde cloudy appearance, the way a Hefe should look.  Smells of banana, cloves, yeast. Tastes divine. This is a perfect example of a Hefe in all ways. It just doesn't get much better than this. Franziskaner has been my favorite Hefe for years, but this one just might have surpassed that as of late. It's at least tied for first.  Crisp, refreshing, almost creamy mouthfeel. Exceptional. Made by the world's oldest brewery. There's a reason why they are still around after nearly 1000 years, because this beer is incredible!

A: A foggy yellow color that has a two finger head that quickly dissipates.  S: Not good at all. It has the aroma of mildewy wheat.  T: Better than expected but still not great. It has the wheat flavor that is expected with some other subtle smells in the background.  M: Average with average carbonation.  O: I imagine that this is a good hefeweizen but I am generally not a fan of this style.

Lovely head, lasts forever. Nice layered appearance. Awesome carbonation streams floating up from the edges of the glass (weizen). Smells a little citrus, banana. Tastes fresh, fizzy and smooth. Leaves a light, bubbly aftertaste that hangs around. Fills my mouth well and seems to hit on every taste bud - sweet, tart, bitter and then salty - in that order. Only a hair thin for feel but otherwise a hefty, proven brew. Overall, a great Hefe!

A staple among hefeweizen's. This beer dominates with a banana and clove taste and aroma. I used to drink tons of this and now I can't just because it's so darned carbonated. It is however, as someone who does not drink many session beers, one of the better session imports one can find.

Ok I have reviewed this beer on tap and now I’m returning to the bottled version, which is a beer I have drank for years and always loved. It’s not all that different in either iteration; I may actually enjoy this one a bit more from the bottle. Hazy light orange color. Huge fluffy white head that falls slowly with excellent lacing. Aroma is full of wheat and yeast, lots of the expected banana and clove notes, perhaps a bit lemony with some traces of coriander.  The flavor is incomparable for the style: very pronounced bananas and cloves, lightly toasted malt, very low bitterness without much of a noticeable hop presence. A touch of sweetness. Lemony and yeasty. Crisply carbonated, light in body, extremely refreshing. I’ll take this one over a bland “summer” ale any day of the week. A true classic.

appearance - very hazy golden color. good 3 inch head off a somewhat rough pour, good rentention and lacing.  smell - banana, wheat, cloves, cinnamon  taste - so well balanced and stronger from the smell. cant wait to get back to austria to drink this all the time. follows the nose but more intense and more of the yeast comes through.  mouthfeel - thick bodied for the style, great carbonation, wettens your mouth for a bit and then dries, very nicely made.

A. Cloudy Golden yellow with substantial head  S. Clove, coriander, allspice and citrus fruits  T. Like the smell, Clove, coriander, banana and mild citrus fruits, maybe a hint of vanilla  M. Crisp, clean and refreshing medium bodied hefe  O. Outstanding Hefeweissbier. I can enjoy this on a hot summer day or a cold snowy winters eve and it will hi the spot either way.

a: cloudy pale straw color. thick three fingers of white head that last a good two minutes.  s: sweet fruit and spice  t: mainly bananna and clove.  m: medium to light body with good carbonation. smooth and easy to drink.  o: i must be in the minority because it seems that alot of highly regarded beers are dominated by banannas and clove and it's just not my thing.

Appearance- Pale golden orange with a nice big frothy white head. Very nice looking..  Aroma- Cloves, faint citus and bananas  Taste- CLOVES, a little banana, a little sweetness... cloves... wait a little bit more clove.  Feel- Nice and smooth, with high carbonation.  It's something I wouldn't drink a lot of... If the clove flavor wasn't so upfront I would like it more.

Bottle enjoyed next to a NG Dancing Man Wheat.  Pours a hazy golden color with a generous whitish head. Looks characteristic of the style. The nose is big wheat with suggestions of clove and banana. A touch of lemon. The taste is big wheat and present, but subdued clove and banana and lemon zing. Not the crazy amount of clove that sometimes comes out of these beers, nor a banana bomb. A bit sweeter and not as lemon/peppery than a lot of saisons and not as soda-like in the body, but not as sweet as a lot of Hefes. Really nice, easy drinking, balanced brew. Overall, this is a world class Hefe.

Poured into a Shock Top Hefe glass. Cloudy and light yellow in color. Tons of carbonation bubbles lead to a large three finger head. Head is quite soapy looking from the side and rocky looking from the top and bright white in color. Lace seems to be quite sticky.  Smell is mostly biscuity or yeast. Some spice and banana.  Taste is sweet and bready. I have a hard time describing the flavors I get from this style. Musty, dank comes to mind first. Hay and earth come next. ???  Mouth is crisp with light carbonation, a light body and an average to long finish.  Overall I didn't enjoy this, but that doesn't mean it's not good beer. I really hate this style so it makes it really hard to review them. I hope I never acquire a taste for these either because I believe I would be heading backwards. That being said, I think this is exactly what the style is looking for and if I weren't such a DIPA guy I might have given this a high 4. Thanks to Skip for the sample.

Pours a cloudy golden-hay color. Big frothy white head. Sampled alongside the Hefeweissbier Dunkel. Both have big clove, banana and bubble gum aromas, though this one is more prominent in the nose. Moderate carbonation. I have to admit that I don't care much for hefeweizens, but this I can enjoy.

Poured into a pint glass.  A - Pours a hazy deep golden blonde color with a thick white bubbly head. Excellent retention.  S - Fresh wheat smell with notes of banana, cloves, and citrus.  T - Wheat with the complexity of fruit and spice flavors from the yeast (similar, but not exactly the same as the nose). A tasty brew.  M - Medium-bodied, thicker on the tongue. Nice carbonation levels, very refreshing.  An excellent hefeweizen, I heartily recommend Weihenstephaner's Hefeweissbier. To me, it's the definitive version of this style readily available.

The only other weizen I had where Paulaner from tap and Hofbraü so this is my first weizen review. Poured into a 400ml Wieckse glass.  A beautiful beer, hazy golden/orange with a rocky, very German, head. I love German foam! The head slowely sinks into itself leaving a rocky landscape in the glass. Lots of carbonation.  Woah! This smells fruity! Banana, mango, pine and indeed clove (I smelled real clove a little earlier). Grainy and some hops.  (Just had spicey food.) Taste is grainy (wheat) and sweet. Very mild bitterness. A creamy banana desert like flavour with some clove in there. Very summery indeed. Unfortunatly it is cold outside now...  Thin/medium mouthfeel with lots of carbonation.

From tasting notes 10-8-11 Poured into a snifter  Appearance: Hazy golden pour with a three finger white head that settles pretty slowly and leaves a spotty lace behind. Impressive replenishing head retention, especially for a hefeweizen.  Smell: Great wheat smell with aromatic yeast as well, and just a hint of some fresh pine-like aroma.  Taste: Wheat, lots of yeasty taste that imparts a bit of spiciness. Interesting aftertaste--almost nutty or woody?  Mouthfeel: Medium-light body, medium-high carbonation, crisp finish. Very nice.  Overall: A very good beer, true to style, top notch in all respects.

Enjoyed at Loreley's in NYC.  Had this side by side with a Franziskaner Hefe on tap in the same kind of glassware.  A - Poured into a 1L Hofbrau mug. Hazy orange medium orange in color with a large white fluffy head. OK retention but really good lacing.  S - Spice, clove, banana, wheat, the aroma was more pronounced than the Franziskaner I compared it with.  T - Wow, just fantastic. Wheaty and really complex. More complex than the nose lets on but with all the same sort of flavor profiles.  M - Exactly what youd expect. Palate coating and almost heavy on the tongue which was unexpected but enjoyable. The carbonation really cleanses your palate.  O - I must say I enjoyed this one just slightly better than the Franziskaner I had side by side with them. But it was such a small margin that it was almost non-existent. World class stuff here. From the claimed oldest brewery in the world you wouldnt expect anything less.

From my beer journal. Reviewed in Mid May 2011.  A: Cloudy golden color with a fantastic and dense head. Lots of lacing. This was a beautiful beer.  S: A great malty/wheat sweetness and a light lemon.  T: Malty sweetness with cloves and bananas interplay. The tiniest of hop finish.  M: Light to medium mouthfeel.  O: This hefeweizen knocked my socks off. I was under the impression I didn't care for hefeweizens... Weihenstephaner taught me a much needed lesson!

pours an unfiltered golden with three fingers of head.  smell is sweet with fruit and molasses.  taste is very light and crisp. the wheat flavor comes through with some hops also.  mouth is light with very good carbonation.  very good beer. light and extremely enjoyable.

Pint bottle poured into a Pilsner glass 10-16-11  I was really excited to drink this beer from the "oldest brewery" in the world.  A: Poured a thick, creamy head, three finger width. Cloudy amber color.  S: Fruity and nutty, wasn't overpowering while remaining a fairly pleasant aroma.  T: Definite nutty sort of taste with some kind of banana tone, to be honest it tasted sort of like banana bread. I really enjoyed it though.  M: For the flavor of the beer it was perfect.  Overall: Was excited to have it, and was not disappointed. The Light smell and flavor really accented the general tone of the beer as one that is well made.

Can't add a lot to all the previous reviews, but in a nutshell :-  Pours a dense white two finger head (did not pour bottle in one go) straw coloured body.  Aromas of bananas, cloves, tinned pears. Compex and delightful.  Taste is light restrained as aromas plus yeast flavours, mouthfeel light, crisp, sharp in a good way.  Great brew as on a one-off drink or an all nighter.

Enjoyed this 12oz bottle out of a large snifter glass.  A: Light murky orange brew with an Enormous 4-finger white head after a violent pour. Head last forever (just like I like it – pun intended) and eventually ends in a very persistent lace.  S: Spicy malt wheat aroma that has a heavy yeast backbone.  T: Malted wheat and barley flavor hits you up front. Every sips reveals this beer’s complexity as it has a great yeast, banana clove, and bitterness makeup. Finished very clean and crisp with mild hints of alcohol.  M: Medium body and medium carbonation  O: I am not a big fan of this style, but I have heard so many good things about this beer I had to try it. It didn’t disappoint, but also didn’t blow me away. It was very well balanced and easily drinkable, but nothing I would grab again.

Bottle (2011)  Super Junior Market San Diego, CA  Just barely hazy golden yellow, orange, and amber with a huge, thick, persistent white head. This beer wasn't nearly as cloudy and hazy as others I've had within style. Spots of lace down the glass.  A powerful aroma of banana, perhaps some apple and pear, clove, and wheat. The best smelling hefeweizen I've ever come across.  Flavor is incredibly similar to the aroma: lots of banana and clove, low bitterness, a bit of white fruit, wheat, and bread. Fantastic!  Light to medium bodied--incredibly drinkable. This beer wants you to drink more and more of it.  I couldn't even imagine a better hefeweizen.

Clear,with just a touch of haziness, golden orange with a large 1 1/2 finger frothy eggshell colored head with excellent retention and mild lacing.  Big earthy and fresh nose with lots of sweet banana, smooth wheatiness and a little bready yeast.  Great flavor burst right off the bat. Same notes as the nose with nice notes of banana, wheat and a little bready. Great balance and a nice and pleasant clean aftertaste.  Light bodied with zesty high carbonation that is just perfect for this beer.  Overall just an outstanding all around hef. Definitely my favorite of the style.

1pt .9oz bottle properly poured into a weizen glass.  A: Cloudy, deep golden in color. Almost orange at its core. Frothy, creamy white head has great retention, as expected. Clumps of sticky lacing are prevalent.  S: Heavy phenols: lots of clove. Over-ripe bananas, bready wheat, powdery yeast.  T: Tastes of banana bread and over-ripe bananas are interrupted by clove and spices. Big dose of wheat. Bready with a touch of that acidity and citrus-like tastes that tend to come with wheat beers. Yeast plays a major role, contributing a mildly chalky and slightly funky taste. Dries a bit toward the finish and the malt tastes turn cracker-like.  M: Very light in body, very fluffy and creamy in the mouth. Lots of aggressive, small-bubbled carbonation, as expected.  O: An excellent beer, maybe the best of the style.  Notes: I am fortunate enough to have this beer frequently available fresh on tap at several bars in the area. It is always excellent, an easy A+ and one of my personal favorite beers. This is my second time having it out of the bottle, and the edge seems to be taken off of it just a bit. I suspect this is due to the rigors of trans-Atlantic shipping, or maybe it isn't quite as fresh as it could be (no bottled-on dates).

I bought this at the liquor store Mitra in Flushing for 1 Euro! I'm not really a fan of the style but I do not want to miss a good beer.  A - I vaguely cloudy yellow liquid with a white head. Carbonated bubbles are not visible.  S - Barley malt, some lemon, not so special and / or fresh.  T - For a wheat beer it is nice and mild flavor, slightly acid with light lemon tones. Not really bitter and quite dry.  M - The carbonation is medium with a slight bitterness in the finish. Not sticky, a very drinkable beer.  O - Good white beer and good enough to try again.

A: A golden color that is slightly cloudy. A large 4 finger off white head is formed.  S: Yeast, citrus, and banana.  T: Yeast and a little bit of clove is present. This beer is dominated by yeast and it also has a slight spice to it, which is much enjoyed. Banana is there, but in the background.  M: Very smooth with good carbonation.  O: This is an excellent beer. My favorite for the style and is a must try.

An old favorite, 16oz brown bottle poured in pint glass.  A- cloudy orange color- make sure to swirl and pour the remnants of the bottle for a nice sediment flowing through the glass.  S- Sweetie and wheaty.  T/M- Creamy with enough carbonation to enlighten the palate to a sweet, yeast taste with hints of banana. Excellent.  One of the best hefeweizens always holds a place in the fridge.

Poured from a 500ml bottle into my Pilsner Glass. Honey golden, very hazy color, 3 fingers of fluff, which takes a couple minutes to dissipate. Smells classically Hefe. Banana, cloves, some floral notes. A bit of citrus. Definitely smells sweet. Tastes more spicy than it smells, with a more subdued banana flavor. A nice hop bitterness on the finish. Very lightly sweet. Lots of little bubbles making me want to burp. Fantastic.

A: The beer pours a hazy gold color with a healthy 2 fingers of head. N: Aromas jump out of the glass and consist of grains and yeast. T: The flavors are more subtle than I expected from the nose. Yeast is the dominant flavor but it does not completely overpower the banana in the background. Lemongrass lingers on the tongue to create a crisp finish. M: The mouthfeel is creamy and full with fairly pronounced carbonation. O: This is an enjoyable brew and I can see how it has become an icon of the style. I'm not a huge hefeweizen fan, but this is a great representative of the style and I'm sure I will find myself returning to this beer when the situation calls for it.

From the bottle to a weizen glass.  The pour is a hazy yellow wheat that is topped by a rocky head that wants to stick around and leave some lace. Getting into the nose I pick up the requisite banana, clove and yeast. Maybe a piece of bubble gum. Taste is on par with the nose and all anyone can really ask for. Banana and clove balance nicely and the yeast lends a nice background for those flavors to work on. Creamy in the mouth with ample carbonation make for a refreshing brew.  My favorite hefeweissen and one I continue to come back to.

A- Orange straw colored hazy body, with a nice billowing cushy white head.  S- Lots of wheaty banana aroma along with a touch of spice.  T- The malty wheaty character gives it a sweetness along with the fruitiness of the banana, then comes the clovey spiciness. A bit watery though I have had this brew many times and never noticed that.  M- Full, lots of carbonation.  O- Top notch Hefe, really sets the standard.

Presentation: 12oz brown pop top, classy, classic label; Some date code that I'm not exactly sure what it means, but I THINK it's at least brewed in 2011, which I'll take, considering I've seen examples that are over 2 years old on the shelf.  Appearance: Hazy dark straw gold beer, with a nice cream-colored cap which, surprisingly, fades a bit fast for my liking.  Smell: Requisite sweet/tart banana aromas, with plenty of spice in the background. A couple of swirls really brings out the spice aromas. Very slight hint of citrus in the background, as well as something nicely floral as this warms a bit.  Taste: Banana and sweet spice (no particular baking spice is coming out here, though I think perhaps I get a slight hint of clove). Slightly tangy wheat backbone, with light, if firm bitterness. All in all, it's a bit like banana bread, though w/out the typical caramelly/burnt sugar notes that confection often (though not always) has.  Mouthfeel: Spritzy and refreshing  Overall: A really tasty Hefeweizen. Is it the world's best, like I once thought? I don't know, though it's certainly top-tier. I do have to say, however, that it's no longer quite my favorite. Overall, however, certainly a tasty offering.

On tap at Beermarket in Toronto. Pours hazy orange with a huge white head. Nose is of yeast, banana, bubble gum and cloves. Medium, slightly crisp, creamy body. Yeast, banana, bubble gum and cloves combine on the palate in a wonderful complexity. Long, balanced finish. I’m not a fan of hefe, but this one is outstanding brew.

A - Hazy orange/yellow, more yellow color with 3 fingers of creamy foamy white head. Lacing is slight, but the head takes a lot to fade.  S - Bready yeasts, lemon, pepper, bubblegum, banana, in order of strength. The bready yeasts, lemon and pepper are the most dominant by far while the others are in the background.  T - Pretty much reverse the dominant flavors from the smells. Bubblegum, banana, lemon, pepper, then the yeasts. Sweet malts show as well with a nice tart overall taste.  M - Thin to medium bodied, good level of carbonation. Finish is slightly drying with that tart taste staying around for a while. When that fades, you're left with the sweet malts sticking to the inside of your mouth.  O - I'm not generally a fan of hefes but I can easily see why this one is considered one of the best.

I decided to open my bottle of Hefewissbier after having a hefeweizen by Ranger Creek Brewery. (based out of San Antonio) I'd have to say my suspicions were accurate. This hefeweizen by Weihenstephaner definitely blows out a lot of other examples by a wide margin.  The beer has a wonderful unfiltered appearance without being too dark like the Ranger Creek one. The foam rose nicely and it subsided fairly slowly. The taste is the most critical component. The last thing I want is to have a hefeweizen taste musty, stagnant, or just plain old. This beer doesn't do that. It had plenty of citrus notes, but it wasn't overly powering nor syrupy to a point where it does taste old.  The beer was easy on my plalate,a nd it actually felt refreshing in my mouth. It was not too syrupy, thick, nor too thin.  Overall, it's a truly great example of hefeweizen, and it's definitely easy to drink. I have to admit, I actually preferred the Kristall Weissbier, but this one is just too dang good.

Appearance: a picturesque cloudy gold color with a fluffy white head.  Smell: some yeast spiciness, milled grain, and lemon; very pleasant aroma.  Taste: perfectly executed subtle fruit esters; apricot, lemon, and orange.. fresh wheat with a faint yeast and clove-like spice. The flavors are incredibly balanced; nothing too overpowering.  Mouthfeel: the ample carbonation is perfect. Lively and refreshing. Medium body.  Overall: My favorite Hefeweizen thus far.. and very reasonably priced. Extremely quaffable. I should always keep a bottle of this stuff in my fridge!

330 ml bottle apparently dated Feb. 2011. Most sediment added. {revised with fresh bottle in April 2014}  Pours with a large whitish head that quickly reduces to a paper thin coat but leaves some lacing. Cloudy golden tone.  Has a very sweet and fruity aroma with suggestions of banana, pineapple, melon and baked bread. Beyond these it is also yeasty. These aromas appear in the taste, along with clove, allspice, apple juice and wheat.  Light body; crisp with slightly aggressive carbonation.  Clearly not an average beer and clearly exceptional for style. However, I often find this style mostly unappealing. Nonetheless, I did find this one to be appealing and refreshing. Hope to sample at the source in Bavaria in 2012.

A- Super clear truly straw colored beer. The off white banana white colored head is huge and rocky.  S- Smells like bananas and cloves and hops. Awesomeness  T- Tastes like it smells, there is a grass hoppy taste as well.  M- The mouthfeel has a slight chewy feel too it. Obviously is carbonated nicely.  O- It's a solid beer, solid for the style. Extremely affordable, extremely tasty

Poured from a 11.2oz bottle into a Czechvar pilsner glass. Freshness code translate to being bottle in April 2011, so roughly 6 months old.  A - hazy straw yellow. Good bright white head, decent lacing.  S - Bananas, clove, Hawiian sweet bread.  T - Lemony, then banana, ends with spicey clove, but also dries out nicely, not to be too sweet.  M - Medium high carbonation. Goes well with the light flavors of this beer.  D - High. Low ABV. Clean taste and very refreshing.  I think this one was a little past its prime. I have had it on tap at the Yardhouse with much better results. But still an excellent beer.

A - Hazy orange amber, Huge frothy head, be careful pouring this beer! Lots of carbonation.  S - Fresh wheats, banana.  T - Banana like candy, refreshing yeasts. Of course you have your cloves.  F - Like a Fresh cream soda, not on its flavor but on the actual feel, this is present even on the front. Body is not too thin though, almost perfect in it's balance.  O - Alright I surrender this has to be one of my fav German beers. I am a hop head, but this Beer gives me a nice break.

11.2 oz brown bottle poured into one of my weizen glasses.  A - Hazy yellowish-orange color. Very beautiful cloudy like look. Nice pure white head and sticky lace.  S - Sweet maly aroma. I picked up numerous fruits. Bananas and a mild lemon were the highlights. A hint of spicey cloves as well as a very nice wheat aroma.  T - Sweet malt taste is to die for. Best part of this brew. Lemons and ripe banana followed by a touch of spices. The sweet wheat taste is simply unbelievable as this brew has a world class taste from start to finish.  M - Smooth and delicious. Medium in body. Very clean tasting and easy to drink. Solid carbonation.  O - This continues on a long list of excellent Hefeweizens I've experienced. One of the best available anywhere in the world. I'll enjoy many more of these for sure. A must try for anyone looking for a top tier hefe.

11.2oz bottle poured into a Snake River pint glass. Looks like I need some wheat beer glassware.  A: Pours a cloudy golden orange/yellow, with an enormous foamy white head.  S: Banana, clove and spices, wheat and sweet bread, some bubble gum, and a creamy/lactose aroma.  T: Follows the nose, spicy banana and wheat bread, sweet malty characters and yeast esters.  MF: Smooth, wet, lighter medium body, good medium carbonaion. Touches of lingering tartness.  O: An excellent heff, no wonder this beer is rated so high. It should be the flagship beer for the style; consistent, simple, and uber-drinkable. Recommended.

consumed at room temp (cold aussie spring night, approx 20degC).  Poured into a stein, produced large head, which over time reduced to think foam, leaving light lacing initially. Liquid is cloudy butterscotch.  Smell is bready, with tropical fruit, maybe some orange peel in the mix.  Taste is malty and delicious, very bready.  Mouthfeel - Highly recommend consuming at room temp only, as it's well carbonated, so this serves to make it a smooth drink. Very creamy mouthfeel...mmm.  Overall, this beer is thick and heavenly, definitely a go-to beer if you're having a german-themed night. I love this beer.
